dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. DAY
dialogues.text: A terribly English face, its pale skin flushed in the cri springtime sun. Short, fair hair. Jacket and tie. A highl intelligent face, persuasive too. The face of a fifty-yea old man who is sitting, legs crossed, in the pretty garde a hotel. Slightly behind him sit two younger assistants. And behind them, a beautiful swimming pool. Only a few bathers, all of them wrapped in identical, soft white rob A lazy, early morning, vacation atmosphere. Jacuzzis dot the flawless lawn around the pool. In the background, a magnificent hotel. Welcoming, dignif and luxurious all at once. And framing the hotel, reigning over it, are the mountain The fifty-year-old man takes out a pack of cigarettes and about to light up when a calm, uncritical voice warns him

dialogues.speaker: CALM VOICE
dialogues.text: You canвЂ™t smoke here.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: Not even outside?

dialogues.speaker: CALM VOICE
dialogues.text: Not even inside. The calm voice belongs to the man sitting across from him English, about eighty years old, in a soft beige jacket a trousers, and eyeglasses with imposing black frames, behi which nest watery, light blue eyes, laden with melancholy cunning. WeвЂ™re talking about Fred Ballinger. ThereвЂ™s a small table between them. An open newspaper i front of Fred. He is calm, placid, serene, but a vague disenchantment hovers in his eyes. In what we realize is habitual gesture, he unwraps a candy and pops it in his mouth. HeвЂ™s clearly a regular consumer of such candies.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Mr. Ballinger, or may I call you Maestro? Fred Ballinger shrugs his shoulders. It really doesnвЂ™t to him. FIFTY-YEAR OLD (CONTвЂ™D) And may I ask how your holiday is going?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been coming here long?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: For more than twenty years. I used to come with my wife. Then I kept coming on my own, I have many friends here.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: Why Switzerland, Maestro?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: It's close to Italy. And I directed the Venice orchestra for twenty- four years. After London and New York, of course.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: But of course, how silly of me! This must also be a very good place to relax.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s only a place to relax. The fifty-year old smiles. Fred doesnвЂ™t.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: Are you still directing or composing, Maestro?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, IвЂ™m retired.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: It goes without saying, of course, that I, like everyone else, ama great admirer of yours.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Thank you. The fifty-year old smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: Maestro, as I indicated to you in my letter, I work for the Ceremonies and Events Office at Buckingham Palace. Fred stirs slightly when he hears this.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You work for the Queen?

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Well, in a sense, yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Monarchies are always so endearing.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: (surprised) If I may, Maestro, why exactly do you find the monarchy endearing?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Because itвЂ™s so vulnerable. Eliminate just one person and all of a sudden the whole world changes. Like in a marriage.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Her Majesty the Queen would be honored to confer a knighthood upon you this coming June, Maestro. A little smile darts across Fred's face.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Do you know what Satie said when he was offered the Legion of Honor? вЂњItвЂ™s not enough simply to refuse it, you also have to not deserve it.вЂќ But I am not Satie. And you must excuse me, I have the most dreadful habit of quoting other people.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Her Majesty will be delighted to learn you have accepted.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Her Majesty has never been delighted about anything. Embarrassed, the QueenвЂ™s emissary skates over FredвЂ™s

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: What is more, your investiture just happens to coincide with the birthday of His Royal Highness The Prince Philip, and the Queen would very much like to give hima concert with the London Philharmonic Orchestra at the New Wimbledon Theatre, to which the Prince is deeply attached, for reasons unknown to me. Her Majesty would be delight-- honored if you would agree to conduct, your own compositions of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I havenвЂ™t conducted for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: (smiles) IвЂ™m sure you haven't forgotten how itвЂ™s done. Fred Ballinger ponders this.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, I havenвЂ™t forgotten how itвЂ™s done. The QueenвЂ™s emissaryвЂ™s smiles radiantly.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Prince Philip and Her Majesty will be simply ecstatic to hear you conduct your famous вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ In a remarkably calm, resigned voice, Fred says:

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Ah, but I will not conduct any of my вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Personal reasons.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: The great soprano Sumi Jo has agreed to sing.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Sumi Jo won't do.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Well then, tell me which soprano would do, and you shall have her.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No one will do. Fred BallingerвЂ™s refusal seems irrevocable. He goes bac reading the paper, all the flattery already behind him. T emissary is devastated. He lowers his head. Silence. Only a slight noise. The camera moves to discove what it is. Fred is rubbing the plastic-coated candy wrap between his fingers at regular intervals. Without a doubt the quick, alternating tempo creates a distinct musical rhythm. The QueenвЂ™s emissary puts a cigarette between his lips about to light it when he remembers that smoking is not permitted. He stammers out one last, lame attempt.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: If I may, Maestro, the Queen might take your refusal rather poorly, sheвЂ™s not used to being told no. Fred Ballinger, who is reading the paper, interrupts ex abrupto rubbing the candy wrapper.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sure she will come to terms with it. There are far more important things in life than my Simple Songs. The emissary is disconsolate.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY
dialogues.text: Well then, I shall relay our conversation to the Queen. Good day, Maestro. The emissary takes his leave. His two assistants follow h When they get up, we see that there is a man sitting behi them, who looks as if he has overheard the whole conversation. His name is Jimmy Tree. HeвЂ™s thirty-four years old, Californian, drop dead handsome, a Hollywood star. Though itвЂ™s still early, heвЂ™s eating a steak and French frie Hiding behind sunglasses and a few days' razor stubble, wearing an unflattering baseball cap and sloppy clothes, looks undone. The three Englishmen are circumnavigating the pool on the way out of the garden, when someone suddenly catches the emissaryвЂ™s attention. This someone is floating in the pool: a man about fifty, his face above water. A puffy, South American face, hair a surreal yellow, full lips, tired features, dark, intelligent eyes, and furrows far too deep for a man his He stares blankly into space. The emissary gazes at the South American and whispers to of his assistants. FIFTY-YEAR OLD EMISSARY (CONTвЂ™D) Do you see that man? Could it really be him? His two assistants turn to look at the man in the pool, a recognize him immediately. They get all excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why yes, it is!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Good god, it really is him. The three Englishmen keep walking, but they canвЂ™t keep glancing furtively at the South American who, with the he of a woman in her forties and three lifeguards, whom he l on like a dead weight, is getting out of the pool. He struggles up the low stairs, which to him seem insurmountable. As he slowly emerges from the water, we see how extraordinarily obese he is, and how much trouble he has walking. Panting, this cumbersome yet charismatic creatur settles himself at the edge of the pool. His arms are swarming with tattoos: faces of famous heroes from famous revolutions. The lifeguards withdraw. The forty-year-old woman with a kindly, patient face is h companion, apparently. She sits next to him and lovingly his hair with a towel, caring for this immense whale. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VENICE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Guitar notes - irregular, sporadic, imploded, muffled sou that seem to come from the deepest depths of the sea or y own conscience - surface now and then during the scene. What we see next is like a vision. A breathtakingly beautiful vision: high water in a desert Saint MarkвЂ™s Square. That vast space, with its unforget porticos and palaces, is now a square lake, water lapping the columns. A narrow, raised walkway intersects the Square. But there no one on it, at least not right now. Then, in the dead of night in this most mysterious city, Ballinger appears at the far end of the long walkway. Lik all old people, he looks vulnerable as he shuffles along, taking tiny, trying steps. Fred looks up and espies a statuesque female figure comin toward him from the other end of the walkway. They move toward each other, the only human beings in this surreal, submerged Venice. TheyвЂ™re closer now, theyвЂ™re about t With ill-concealed amazement, Fred fixes his eyes on the woman: sheвЂ™s 6/1". An impossible beauty, with black hair and eyes so green seem fake, wearing a one-piece bathing suit and a sash th says MISS UNIVERSE. SheвЂ™s even closer now, approaching him with the solemn, inhuman gait of a top model in a big-time fashion show. They're about to meet. But the walkway is only three feet wide, so they both move aside to let the other pass witho falling in the water. ItвЂ™s inevitable that they touch. Universe's plentiful decolletГ© brushes against FredвЂ™s chest. He gazes up at her from below, as if he were beholding a benign tragedy. Like all beauty queens, she stares coldly into space, not even noticing her perfect body's fleeting contact with Fr Having avoided a mishap, they each proceed on their way. beauty queen sways off into the full moon, surrounded by expanse of water, like in some debatable Dolce & Gabbana dream. Fred shuffles along the walkway. HeвЂ™s afraid now, and w good reason: the water is rising quickly, flooding the walkway and swirling around his feet, his ankles, his kne Fred tries to hurry, but heвЂ™s old and the water tugs at legs. He turns and cries out in a suffocated voice, as if begging Miss Universe for help.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Melanie, Melanie! But Miss Universe is no longer there, itвЂ™s as if she evaporated. Fred keeps going, but not for much longer. The water is u his chest now, his neck, his chin, heвЂ™s panicked, a sti guitar note sounds, when, luckily...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: .+. he wakes up. Fred quickly regains his composure. He struggles up from his chair. ItвЂ™s late. No oneвЂ™s arou Except for a small crowd of guests in the distance, real night owls. The guitar notes flow now, crisp and real. Fred takes tiny steps toward them, the underwater pool li providing a shadowy glow. As he shuffles across the deserted lawn, the OPENING CRED start to roll, and a voice joins in with the guitar, itвЂ coming from the little group of people. The song is вЂњOnward,вЂќ a magnificent, somber, America ballad. Fred instinctively heads toward the music. Fred hovers near the edge of the gathering, where Mark Kozelek, guitar in his lap, is singing вЂњOnward.вЂќ Thre a twenty-year-old kid, and Jimmy Tree are there as well. little group, all mellow and relaxed, listens contentedly the great American folksinger. The OPENING CREDITS continue to roll as Fred Ballinger, standing slightly apart, listens to the beautiful ballad. Mark Kozelek notices him and is unable to conceal his emo at having such a distinguished spectator. Mark gives a reverential little bow with his head and the during an instrumental break, says to Fred.

dialogues.speaker: MARK KOZELEK
dialogues.text: Maestro. Fred smiles slightly. The OPENING CREDITS are over. Jimmy Tree is stretched out on the grass, eyes closed. He opens his eyes and sees Fred. They nod hello to each othe then Jimmy gestures aimiably to him to join him. Fred goe over and sits near Jimmy, perching on the edge of a chais lounge. Jimmy offers him a mug.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: I slipped a bit of gin and tonic into the herbal tea. Interested, Mr. Ballinger?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I'd prefer a bit of herbal tea slipped into a gin and tonic. They both smile. Fred takes out a cloth handkerchief, quickly blows his no expertly folds his handkerchief and, in a habitual gestur has clearly done a million times, quickly wipes his nose times, then puts his handkerchief back in his jacket pock Jimmy Tree, an irresistible smile on his face, has observ FredвЂ™s handkerchief routine with utmost attention.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: I was thinking today that you and I have the same problem.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Is that so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been misunderstood our whole lives because we allowed ourselves to give in - just once - toa little levity.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Perhaps. Because levity is an irresistible temptation.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve worked with all the great European and American directors, but IвЂ™1l be remembered forever for Mister Q, for a fucking robot. I had to wear a suit of armor that weighed two hundred pounds, you couldnвЂ™t even see my face. But every five minutes someone has to come up and remind me that I did Mister Q, the same way they remind you that you did those вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ And they forget that you also composed вЂњThe Black Prism,вЂќ вЂњThe Life of Hadrian,вЂќ and all the rest. Fred Ballinger smiles and so does Jimmy. TheyвЂ™re accomp now.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Because levity is also a perversion. What are you doing in Europe?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m doing a new film, in Germany, starting in a month. IвЂ™m developing the role.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Is it a lighthearted role?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: That depends on your point of view.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Is it coming along well?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: We'll see. Mark Kozelek breathes the last note of вЂњOnward.вЂќ The group claps languidly. Fred doesnвЂ™t join in. Then, stru to get up, he takes his leave of Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s late for me.  10.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Not for me. Fred smiles. Jimmy salutes him playfully, two fingers to temple. Fred moves off with the uncertain gait of an old man. Jim drinks and observes Fred's slow walk.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL RECEPTION/ELEVATOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fred Ballinger stands immobile in the lobby, across from reception desk. HeвЂ™s waiting for the elevator. A young night doorman stares blankly at a small, silent T A very petite, dignified-looking woman, who looks older t her sixty years, rings the doorbell. The doorman, without taking his eyes off the TV, presses a button and buzzes h in. The woman enters and sits on a bench. Melancholy and resigned, she stares into space. Fred Ballinger, still waiting for the elevator, has watched all this, his face expressionless. Finally, the elevator. An old contraption with a metal gr Fred steps inside. The elevator ascends. We see his silhouette rising.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL ELEVATOR/CORRIDOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It stops at his floor. A chubby, unattractive young woman about twenty, is waiting to take the elevator down. Her f is pocked here and there with pimples, an adolescent peculiarity that clashes with her sharp, aggressive look. can safely assume that sheвЂ™s a hooker, but a hooker sui generis. Fred forgets to look at her, and she pays no attention to him. Alone, Fred Ballinger makes his way down the hallway, tak tiny, slow steps. Next to every door are pairs of hiking boots, neatly arranged, which the guests have put out to aired. In the silence of the night, an old man in an electric wheelchair overtakes Fred and vanishes around a corner. The sound of a violin comes from one of the rooms, stoppi Fred in his tracks. He turns, searching for the source. I starts up again, from the beginning: only two notes, play poorly. SomeoneвЂ™s obviously practicing, one of those re tedious exercises. Fred takes a step in the direction of the sound, but it s again.  11. He is about to keep walking when he encounters his reflec in a mirror. He touches a sunspot on his temple, which he notices for the first time there in the mirror. 5. INT. MICK BOYLEвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT Those same violin notes start up again, but extra-diegeti now, and perfectly executed. They give life to a soft, melancholic music. We're in a room where confusion reigns: papers and notes spread all over the place, laptop computers left open and forgotten. Five kids - four guys and a girl - all under thirty, are sleeping, curled up in armchairs scattered he and there, and on the bed. They are sleeping the sleep of just. Fred Ballinger and another elderly man are standing in th room, he too about eighty years old, still attractive, hi hair a little long, his bright, sparkling eyes omnivorous full of life. His name is Mick Boyle. The two old men silently observe the sleeping kids. The violin vanishes. After a while.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Did you take a piss today?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Twice. Four drops. You?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Same. More or less.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: More or less?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Less.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Look how beautiful they are.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Beautiful, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: If you only knew how moving it is to see them working on the screenplay. TheyвЂ™re so passionate.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: They've caught your passion.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And have you lost yours?  12. Fred just shrugs. Mick, with what is clearly a habitual gesture, smooths hi hair across his forehead with the palm of his hand, and t changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See those two? He points to the girl and one of the guys, who are sleepi on opposite sides of the room.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Of course I see them.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: They're falling in love, but they don't know it yet. The girl, her eyes still closed, gives a smile that no on sees. Because sheвЂ™s not asleep.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (xreflects)I know because I know everything there is to know about love.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Then you'll have to give me lessons one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: It's late now. Have you heard the latest? Joyce Owens, Miss Universe, is coming to stay. Apparently one of her prizes is a free week in our hotel.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard. But it seems more like a punishment than a prize to me.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Which is just how it should be. Some forms of beauty have to be punished, to make life bearable for the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: HowвЂ™s the screenplay coming along?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s going to be my masterpiece. My testament. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Brenda is going to make an unforgettable leading lady. We hit on the title today: вЂњLifeвЂ™s Last Day.вЂќ What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (reflects) ItвЂ™s good. IвЂ™m going to bed. Fred heads out while in the background Mick shakes one of kids.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Come on, guys, wake up, it's time to go back to your hotel. 6. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT A beautiful woman, about forty, sleeps soundly in the bed Her name is Lena. A sweeping shot of the room. We see the night stand, with framed photograph from ten years ago, of Fred being hugge a woman his age. They smile happily in the photo. We can assume itвЂ™s his wife. The sweeping shot ends on Fred, sitting in a chair. HeвЂ™ staring bright-eyed at the sleeping woman. Lena opens her eyes and sees Fred. SheвЂ™s surprised.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: ArenвЂ™t you sleeping, Daddy? Fred, trying to hide his tears, smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, IвЂ™m looking at you. Lena notices her fatherвЂ™s tears.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: But Daddy, you're...

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (anticipates what she is going to say) DonвЂ™t worry. Old people cry all the time. And for no good reason. 6A. EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. DAWN. Early morning dew. The extensive hotel grounds, punctuate here and there by beautiful, centuries-old trees.  14. The chubby hooker and the petite, sixty-year-old woman we earlier at the reception desk appear, seen from behind. TheyвЂ™re probably mother and daughter. They walk hand in hand, sad and forgotten by the world. With a awkward, inelegant gesture, the girl adjusts her v short shorts, which have annoyingly worked their way in between her buttocks. Mick Boyle is sitting on a bench, looking over his work notes. He senses the presence of the two women and looks His eyes immediately grow melancholy when he sees the mot and daughter walking hand in hand. The sky beyond the high mountain peaks begins to brighten while the dew vanishes from the leaves of the garden's beautiful plants. 7. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. DAY Fred is on his stomach on a massage table. An eighteen-ye old girl, incredibly timid, slight, with delicate feature is giving Fred a massage. Lena looks out the window and sees an Asian man sitting a the far end of the garden.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: That guy who levitates is out there.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve been coming here for years. HeвЂ™s never levitated. So, where is it you decided to go?

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Polynesia. For two weeks. Julian went overboard, as usual.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: (smiling) You'll be glad to have the room all to yourself now. I was in your way.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Not at all. You kept me company. Mick is working and I get bored.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: You wonвЂ™t be bored now. I arranged the full treatment for you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Massage and sauna every day, check- ups with the doctor... to help you get back in shape.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: At my age, getting back in shape is merely a waste of time. IвЂ™m going to be even more bored now.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: You're a victim of your own apathy, Daddy. Why donвЂ™t you go to Venice one of these days? You could bring flowers to Mummy. Fred doesnвЂ™t answer. The masseuse is very discreet, itвЂ™s as if she werenвЂ™t listening.

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, the French write to me every day. TheyвЂ™re really insisting that you write your memoirs. What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Let them insist. Lena stares at her naked father being massaged. His body worn with age. A wave of tenderness washes across her fac Sad now, she takes her leave.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Bye, Daddy, IвЂ™1ll call you when we get there.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Have fun. Lena wheels her carry-on out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MASSEUSE
dialogues.text: (Swiss accent) Would you mind turning over on your back, please? Her voice is that of a young girl, which makes her even m charming. Fred turns over, though not without difficulty. masseuse starts rubbing his arms. His eyes are closed, but he opens one slightly, on the sl to look at the girlвЂ™s face.  16.

dialogues.speaker: 7A/1
dialogues.text: The day begins at this enormous compound, which is at onc hotel, a spa, a medical center, a sports complex, and a physical rehab facility. With established rhythms and wel defined schedules. In fact, antique bells ring throughout the hotel, so that guests will not be late for their appointments.

dialogues.speaker: 7A/2 7A/3
dialogues.text: Nurses and masseuses, all in uniform, emerge from sterile changing rooms and head to their work stations.

dialogues.speaker: 7A/4
dialogues.text: Doctors don white coats.

dialogues.speaker: 7A/5 7A/6 7A/7
dialogues.text: The guests, most of them elderly, and all of them wearing identical hotel bathrobes, form orderly lines and head to their check-ups, or to the swimming pools, saunas, and massage rooms. The silent, serene, and sparsely attended activity of a w just set in motion.

dialogues.speaker: 7A/8
dialogues.text: The waiters, backlit, clear tables in the breakfast room.

dialogues.speaker: 7A/9
dialogues.text: An anorexic cook heads out behind the kitchen. Enjoying t first drag on his cigarette, he stares at the clear blue above the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MASSAGE ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Soporific, new age music pervades the room. In the darkness, relieved only by a sea of candles, Fred lying on an enormous straw crib, like an eighty-year-old Jesus. A little Thai man, about fifty, is placing burning black stones on FredвЂ™s body. Fred moans lightly in pain each one touches his skin. The masseur smiles, then says in halting English.

dialogues.speaker: MASSEUR
dialogues.text: After pain come pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: And then pain again.  17.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL INFIRMARY. DAY
dialogues.text: A nurse is drawing FredвЂ™s blood. A doctor, about sixty, comes in. He has a nice, kindly fa

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: HowвЂ™s it going, Mr. Ballinger?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s going. I donвЂ™t know where, but itвЂ™s going. The doctor smiles. Then he stops and looks at FredвЂ™s fa puts his glasses on and examines Fred more attentively. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) My daughter says IвЂ™m apathetic. Is it that obvious?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (smiles) Would you like to have those sunspots removed? We could take them off with a laser.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Because theyвЂ™re unsightly.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: But they remind me of something fundamental.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: That my life is full of spots. The doctor smiles. Fred smiles. The nurse has finished drawing his blood. Fred looks out the window, which frame spotless mountain peak set against an unbelievably blue s Fred is serious now. 10. INT. MICK BOYLEвЂ™S SUITE. DAY The young screenwriters are in the middle of an argument. Mick, immersed in a sea of papers, listens but doesnвЂ™t intervene. Fred comes in, but no one pays any attention to him. They all too embroiled in their argument. So Fred listens impartially.  18. They're all talking at once, itвЂ™s impossible to make ou everything theyвЂ™re saying, but two of them, arguing fie are louder than the others. Naturally, itвЂ™s the boy and the girl who, according to are falling in love.

dialogues.speaker: SCREENWRITER IN LOVE
dialogues.text: You've been watching too many movies, you idiot, youвЂ™ve forgotten what lifeвЂ™s about!

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Movies are life! All you know how to do is criticize. If you only had some inspiration for once. He laughs and claps sarcastically. A shy screenwriter, sitting next to Mick, comments under breath on their argument.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: SCREENWRITER IN LOVE
dialogues.text: Inspiration?! DidnвЂ™t they teach you at film school that inspiration doesnвЂ™t exist? InspirationвЂ™s a lie. ThereвЂ™s no such thing as inspiration, only fermentation.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Inspiration exists, alright, you just don't recognize it, because you have zero talent.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Exactly! Mick, hearing the contradictory remarks coming from the s screenwriter sitting next to him, addresses him harshly.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing? Agreeing with everyone?

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Of course! I'm timid and insecure. My parents never gave me any encouragement. My brother's favorite sport was beating me up. My sister called me "the failure". (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've never had a girlfriend, and I also have serious doubts about my sexual orientation. Mick stifles a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Stop it! YouвЂ™re not going to move me.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: My aunt has polio. Mick laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SCREENWRITER IN LOVE
dialogues.text: (furious) Don't you dare accuse me of having no talent ever again, you idiot.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: NowвЂ™s not the time for fermentation, you untalented parasite.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s enough, youвЂ™re really getting on my nerves. We have to come up with an ending, and youвЂ™re wasting time talking philosophy and big ideas. Fred joins in.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: But theyвЂ™re right, Mick. ItвЂ™s the big ideas that give rise to all the little ones. Only now do the others realize Fred is there.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Oh, Fred, youвЂ™re here. Listen, I still have a couple of hours to go here, and then I have to talk to the doctor. I'll find you after that.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Okay. Sad, and also a bit disappointed because no one even commented on his observation, Fred leaves the room, while Mick hounds his screenwriters.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Well? Come on, whoвЂ™s got an idea for the ending?  20. Another screenwriter, who hadnвЂ™t taken part in the argu speaks up. He has a long beard and tousled hair: the epit of a well-educated, ironic young man. As if having a visi he says dreamily.

dialogues.speaker: INTELLECTUAL SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: So heвЂ™s on his deathbed, he can barely talk, and he whispers to his wife: вЂњDonвЂ™t cry, honey. You know IвЂ™ve always found women who weep frivolous and repulsive.вЂќ The two who had been fighting exchange a conspiratorial l and start to laugh. The timid, insecure screenwriter thinks for a moment and says with confidence.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Nice! Mick throws him a disgusted look, then says.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What a totally asinine idea. What else?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. DAY
dialogues.text: A deep torpor has settled over the hotel guests, as if th been anesthetized. The silence is numbing. In the early morning light, we watch a slow swarm of rich Russians dro onto chaise lounges to sunbathe, and a handsome black American family, immobile in the pool. Off to one corner, outdoor massages are available, in the shade of a beautiful canopy. Two teenage boys, in the swi of a hormonal tempest, are hanging around there, furtivel eyeing a beautiful woman who is getting an gentle, orient style massage. Few guests, all of them wealthy. We can make out a pair of parachutists in the distance, s against the crisp, imposing mountains. An elderly couple has dozed off in their electric wheelchairs. Their Asian caregivers are as discreet and invisible as m A fifty-year old son does gymnastics with his decrepit father.  21. At the far end of the garden, near the hedges that act as fence, the obese South American is leaning on a cane and signing autographs for a whole mix of people, all of whom seem bewitched by their hero. His companion at his side. eternal apprehension, she regulates how much time each pe gets with her husband. Someone takes out a cell and snaps photo on the sly. She is furious and orders a complete moratorium on photos of her husband. Fred Ballinger, wrapped in a white robe and lying on a ch lounge, sucks on a candy and watches, with resigned inter the autograph-signing ritual. One hand dangling off the chaise, he rubs the candy wrapper between his fingers, th irregular tempo creating a clear rhythm. Jimmy Tree is stretched out on a chaise lounge next to Fr He too is studying the South American, but seems more interested in his cane. ItвЂ™s of briarwood, made to look all twisted and full of knots. Jimmy looks around and something else catches his eye: a mother is rubbing suntan lotion on her thirteen-year-old daughter. The girl, so pale you can almost see through her, stares the ground, as if overcome by a pathological timidness. T for no apparent reason - she must have gotten nervous - s starts biting her fingernails, practically devouring them After a while, the mother apparently tells her to stop, because she gets all pissed off, screams at her mother, t gets up and storms off. Jimmy, an unlit cigarette dangling from his lips, studies like an entomologist. The South American, leaning on his cane and his wife, is coming across the garden. They skirt a deserted tennis co But his attention is drawn to a particular: a forgotten tennis ball lies in the middle of the court.

dialogues.speaker: 11A. INT.PHARMACY.DAY
dialogues.text: Fred and Mick stand next to each other at the counter of pharmacy. Fred waits impassively while Mick, glasses perched on the of his nose, checks to make sure that the pharmacist is getting everything right. The pharmacist places a whole range of drugs on the count in front of Mick, creating a veritable "mountain" of medicine.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That's everything.  22.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Good. Mick turns to Fred, and only now does he realize that his friend hasnвЂ™t asked for any medicine for himself. We ca the puzzlement in MickвЂ™s voice as he asks.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t you need anything? So Fred, faking uncertainty, looks around the pharmacy an fixes his gaze on the first shelf he happens to see, whic contains a full selection of Bandaids. Fred grabs a random box of Bandaids and puts it on the counter in front of the pharmacist. Mick has observed Fred's actions closely. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) What do you need Bandaids for?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t. IвЂ™m getting them out of solidarity with you. Mick turns back to his mountain of medicine and speaks in voice that is halfway between serious and humorous. Barel opening his mouth, he says to himself, but as if he were speaking to Fred.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Fuck you. A wry smile appears on Fred Ballinger's face.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY LANE. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred and Mick stroll through a meadow in a beautiful vall with an expanse of trees to the right, and the mountain village to the left. The two friends are chatting.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Why do you think we come here on holiday every year?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Because you always want to go back to the places that made you happy.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (smiles) ThatвЂ™s the screenwriter in you talking.  23.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I wish! Actually, itвЂ™s John Cheever.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Do you remember Gilda?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: The film?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, Gilda Black. The Gilda we both were in love with.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Gilda Black???

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Gilda Black.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (laughs) What are you going and remembering her for? That was a hundred years ago.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: To me it seems like yesterday. I would have given twenty years of my life to sleep with her.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Well that would have been a pretty stupid thing to do! Gilda Black wasnвЂ™t worth twenty years of your life. She wasnвЂ™t worth a single day. Fred is suddenly incredibly disappointed and also somewha apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: How would you know? Did you sleep with her? Mick stammers, he realizes he has put his foot in his mou

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What? What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You heard me. Sixty years ago you swore you never slept with her, out of respect for my love for her. But now youвЂ™ve changed your tune.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Look, I have to confess something.  24.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Fine, go right ahead!

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: The real tragedy -- and believe me, it really is a tragedy -- is that I canвЂ™t even remember if I slept with Gilda Black.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, yes. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Well then, that changes things.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: If you were sure you'd slept with her, our friendship would be over right this second. But if you're not sure, well, letвЂ™s just say... that I can live with the uncertainty.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Anyway, if I did go to bed with her and donвЂ™t remember it, that means she wasnвЂ™t worth twenty years of your life, wouldnвЂ™t you say?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Well yes, I guess youвЂ™re right. So Gilda Black is a closed book between us.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Good. Have the kids left?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Your son wanted to do it up in style: Polynesia.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I know, heвЂ™s a real spendthrift, that one. Who knows where he gets it from.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Not from you, obviously. Mick laughs. Silence. All of a sudden, Fred seems anxious sighs. Mick notices.  25.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What? Are you still thinking about Gilda Black?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No. IвЂ™m thinking about the things you forget over time. I donвЂ™t remember my parents any more. What they looked like, how they talked. Last night I was watching Lena as she slept and I started thinking about all those little things, thousands of them, that I did for her as her father. I did them deliberately, so that she would remember them when she grew up. But in time she wonвЂ™t remember a single one. Mick looks at him but doesnвЂ™t know what to say. ItвЂ™s beautiful moment. Fred meets MickвЂ™s gaze and, with a quickness and vigor is unusual for him, he grabs his friendвЂ™s arm and hisse angrily. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Tremendous efforts, Mick. Tremendous efforts, and all for the most modest results. ThatвЂ™s the way it always is. Mick is surprised, stunned even.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: This conversationвЂ™s getting interesting. I need a cigarette. I left mine in the hotel, though. Wait here, IвЂ™m going to go buy another pack. Fred nods sadly, as if defeated. Mick heads off toward the village. The silence is broken by a cicada singing. Fred turns tow the sound and, as if in a trance, heads toward it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred is in the middle of the woods, where hundreds of cic are singing. Then a strange bird chimes in, making an odd sound, a sordid chirping that can be heard above the cica Fred forgets about the cicadas and heads off in search of bird, drawn to this new noise.  26. He stares up at the trees, hoping to see the mysterious b He crosses the woods, is almost at the other side, when a constellation of sounds is added to the others: cowbells. Fred comes out of the woods and is greeted by a sunny, ge rolling hill. Scattered across it are fifty or so grazing cows, randomly ringing their bells. FredвЂ™s eyes light u the sight. He sits on a rock and stares. He listens to this superimposition of sounds: cows, bird, cicadas. Fred closes his eyes, concentrating now, as the camera sl zooms in on him. Fred begins to move his hand - gently, gracefully, just l an orchestra director - and, as if by magic, some of the cowbells fall silent. Others keep ringing, but no longer anarchic fashion. Now they play in some clearly melodic manner. Fred moves his hand again and silences more bells that only two keep ringing, sounding alternate notes. Nex Fred waves his arm behind him, and the bird comes in. The sweeps both arms wide, inviting the chorus to join in: hundreds of cicadas accompany the bird solo and the cowbe countermelody. A symphony of nature. FredвЂ™s eyes are st closed, he is smiling to himself. The camera has zoomed in to a close-up of FredвЂ™s face. the first time, he looks happy. Mentally selecting the sounds nature offers him, he is do something amazing. He is composing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MEADOW. DAY
dialogues.text: Mick returns to the spot where but thereвЂ™s no sign of him. He As he does so, his eye catches fence in the distance. A white So Mick does the only thing he he left Fred. He looks around, lights a cigarette. something moving behind a horse. knows how to do: he makes a frame with his hands, the way directors do, to simulate t viewfinder of a movie camera. He closes one eye and with frame of his hands he follows, in a panoramic shot, the movement of the beautiful white horse.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. HOTEL. DAY
dialogues.text: A pedestrian bridge leads from the back of the hotel to t mountains. About a dozen staff - waiters, cooks, and nurses вЂ” have congregated here, enjoying their break.  27. They're all smoking, chatting, horsing around; this is th time to relax. All except for one girl, who keeps to hers She smokes too, but doesnвЂ™t talk to anyone. She seems melancholy. She is leaning over the railing, staring down below, but without really seeing anything. ItвЂ™s the mas we saw in Fred's room. Fred is a hotel hallway, standing at a window that looks onto the bridge. His face too is veiled in melancholy as stares at the lonely masseuse who smokes and stares. The sound of that violin, still practicing that same exercise, catches FredвЂ™s attention. Off he goes, search for the source.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL HALLWAY / ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred moves cautiously down the deserted hallway. The viol can be heard more clearly now. He runs into the sixty-yea old doctor with the kindly face, followed by two nurses. and the doctor nod in greeting. Fred comes upon a room, the door open. The chambermaid is just finishing tidying up, and at the far end, standing i front of a mirror with a musical score open in front of h a twelve-year-old boy is practicing those same two notes, over and over and over. The chambermaid leaves, pushing her cleaning cart through door. Fred instinctively steps into the room. He watches the bo play. The child senses someone's presence and turns to lo at Fred. Fred smiles at him. The boy smiles back. Fred is a little worked up.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Do you know who composed the piece you're practicing?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: No, who?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t believe you. WhatвЂ™s it called?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s called вЂњSimple Song No.3.вЂќ The boy checks the title on the cover of his score.  28.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: You're right. And whatвЂ™s the composerвЂ™s name?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Fred Ballinger.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: And you, whatвЂ™s your name?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Fred Ballinger. You can check at the front desk. IвЂ™m staying here. The boy is surprised now.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Incredible.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: My teacher makes me play it, he says itвЂ™s a perfect piece to start with.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s right. Because itвЂ™s simple.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: But itвЂ™s not merely simple.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s not?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: No, itвЂ™s also really beautiful. Fred, cold and impassive, instinctively lets something "h slip.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Yes, it is beautiful. Because I composed it when I still loved. The boy seems not to understand what Fred means, so simpl starts practicing again. Fred listens for a while, then interrupts him. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) May I do something while you play? The boy nods uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: (doubtful) Okay.  29. He starts playing again. Fred steps timidly into the room and shuffles over to the boy, who keeps on playing. Fred stretches out his hand an touches the boyвЂ™s arm, the one holding the bow. He rais boy's elbow an inch, correcting his position. ThatвЂ™s all. Fred is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL RESTAURANT. EVENING
dialogues.text: The lugubrious silence of the rich as they dine. The only sound is the tinkling of silverware. The Russians are there, the black family, and droves of elderly guests. Many eyes are irresistibly drawn to the table where the famous, obese South American dines in silence with his wi At another table, a twenty-year-old kid canвЂ™t resist th temptation to take a picture. He discreetly positions his iPhone. The obese South American, who realizes what the k is doing, merely nods wearily to his wife. She understand immediately, gets up, and goes to get a screen from behin column. She places the screen between her husband and the rest of the room, angling it so as to block the young man view. Then she disappears behind it. Jimmy Tree is eating alone and has followed the scene tha has just unfolded with utmost concentration. Another guest is observing the scene too, a giant of a ma about fifty, with a thick beard, disheveled hair, and dre in trekking gear. He looks like a belated hippy. Tucking cloth napkin into his shirt, he tackles a bowl of broth. The obese South American has finished eating, and now cro the dining room. He moves with considerable effort, leani on his cane and his companion. As he goes by, all the gue look at him again out the corners of their eyes. But JimmyвЂ™s attention is still focused on his briarwood At another table, Fred and Mick. They obsessively observe a very distinguished, German-loo couple, around sixty years old: husband and wife are dres alike, in brown and beige, clearly not by chance. They bo look incredibly bored and stare into space, not exchangin single word. Fred and Mick chat, but never take their eyes off the sil couple.  30.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: So where did you disappear to today?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I got lost following the sounds in the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: DidnвЂ™t you used to get lost in your music too?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Everything one hears is music. Stockhausen. What did you get up to?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I couldn't find you, so I went to see my doctor friend. TheyвЂ™re going to talk tonight, youвЂ™ll see. The married couple still hasnвЂ™t said a word.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Thirty Swiss francs says they wonвЂ™t say a word the entire dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m so sure theyвЂ™re going to talk, I'll raise you to fifty.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Done. The couple is about to leave. He graciously pulls her cha out for her. She takes his arm. They leave the dining roo and Fred and Mick follow them with their gaze all the way the door. The couple still doesnвЂ™t speak. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Including your losses these past few days, weвЂ™re up to 250 Swiss francs that you owe me. Fred blows his nose, then rubs the tip four times with hi handkerchief, folds it, and puts it back in his pocket. Mick Boyle runs his hand over his hair. Jimmy Tree has been studying their every move from his solitary table.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A swing band is trying to liven up the evening with an up number that only ends up making people feel sentimental.  31. Four old men in electric wheelchairs are gathered around small table, absorbed in a card game. A handful of energetic types sway awkwardly on the dance floor. A Russian and his wife twirl around in a sweat, as if the were in a dance competition. He dips her and she laughs. Jimmy Tree, incongruous in his sunglasses, is in a corner chatting with a small group of people, including Mark Kozelek.

dialogues.speaker: MARK KOZELEK
dialogues.text: When did you go to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Pretty early.

dialogues.speaker: MARK KOZELEK
dialogues.text: I would have joined you if you'd called me.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Just as well. I didnвЂ™t just eat at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MARK KOZELEK
dialogues.text: What else did you do?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: I worked. Mick and Fred, at another table, gaze distractedly at the gloomy evening. The upbeat song ends and the band starts in on a slow num Couples form. The eternally mute couple makes its way to the dance floo They dance with conviction, but still donвЂ™t say a word, even look at each other. She keeps her inexpressive eyes Jimmy Tree. He realizes it, lowers his sunglasses and smi courteously at her. She doesnвЂ™t return the smile. She d react at all. Her husband has followed the whole thing, a severe, jealous expression on his face. The hippy mountaineer, sad and solitary, watches the swin band and sips his herbal tea. ItвЂ™s so hot it burns his He lets out a quick but intense groan, which no one hears Mick and Fred give in to a brief, tragic exchange.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Today?  32.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Nothing today. You?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s hope we can piss tomorrow. With enormous effort, the obese South American makes his to the center of the dance floor, leaning on his cane. He smiles and holds out his hand, inviting his wife to dance She beams and runs to join him. They dance for all of ten seconds, during which he struggles against his own body, legs ruined by his weight. Then he stops, completely exhausted. His companion grows anxious and gestures for assistance. Two dutiful waiters carry a chair onto the da floor, and the South American collapses in it, as if fina able to breathe again. Everyone observes the happenings with a grave air. Fred and Mick watch as well. Fred blows his nose in his ritual fashion. Mick, referring to the South American, sa

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: That man is the last true authentic myth on the face of the planet. Like in ancient Greece. If it were anybody else, we would have laughed at this little scene. But not him. No one is laughing. And do you know why?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, why?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Because a myth leaves no room for the ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fred walks down the hallway, away from us. He is overtake an old man in an electric wheelchair. When the man gets t the far end of the hallway, he crashes into another wheelchair, which emerges from the hallway to the right. minor wheelchair accident. An altercation ensues over mat of priority, who has the right of way, and what determine careless driving. Fred watches the whole thing without batting an eye. He p his key in the door and disappears into his room.  33. 18. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT Fred is in his room, getting undressed. HeвЂ™s taking off shirt when he hears an inexplicable, muffled lament comin from the bathroom. He shuffles over to the bathroom door opens it. His daughter Lena is sitting on the edge of the tub, drowning in tears. It goes without saying that Fred is surprised and, at lea for a second, speechless. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Lena doesnвЂ™t answer, she just goes on weeping. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) ArenвЂ™t you supposed to be on a plane to Polynesia? She cries some more. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) WhereвЂ™s Julian? Whatever it is she says sounds like the cry of some stran animal. Impossible to understand. She goes back to crying FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Well, arenвЂ™t you going to answer me? But she doesnвЂ™t answer him. She canвЂ™t. Because she ne cry. 19. INT. MICK BOYLEвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT Mick Boyle, fully dressed, is lying on his bed, which is covered in papers and computers, talking merrily on the phone. His young screen writers are all pacing the room, eyes trained on Mick, eager to know the outcome of his phone conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s great, Nick. IвЂ™m glad you like the second draft... Sure, we'll work some more on the ending, we're not totally happy with it either... I talked to Brenda. EverythingвЂ™s all set... Yes, of course, she canвЂ™t wait. When is she ever going to get offered a part like this again, at her age!... Yeah, I know sheвЂ™s capricious, but she behaves with me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She always says IвЂ™m the best when it comes to actresses, that IвЂ™m the only one in the world who knows how to direct her. So, if itвЂ™s okay with you, I'd like to start scouting out locations next month... perfect. Great... yeah, bye. The screenwriters, pleased with what they hear, grin and each other on the back. Mick puts down the phone and looks up. Only now do we discover the presence of Fred Ballinger sitting impassively in a chair. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) What happened to you? You look like you just came from a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Your son left my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: They were boarding the plane for Polynesia, and right there in the tunnel he stops and tells her heвЂ™s fallen in love with another woman.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Nothing like being in a tunnel to make you feel you're in a tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (ironic) How profound! You're quite the magician of metaphor. The screenwriters snigger.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And then he took this other woman on vacation?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: It seems he at least had the good taste not to do that. At least not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And Lena?  35.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: LenaвЂ™s in my room, crying her eyes out. IвЂ™ve never seen anybody cry so much my whole life. I didnвЂ™t think it was possible to cry that much.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I read in some magazine once that tear ducts can produce tears for three days without stopping.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: I heard that too, but on a BBC documentary.

dialogues.speaker: INTELLECTUAL SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s on his deathbed, and he says to her, "Let's watch one last BBC documentary together, darling."

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Knock it off, guys.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know if itвЂ™s true, though, this thing about the tear ducts. It was in one of those popular magazines, they have a tendency to exaggerate, you know, better for sales.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I think weвЂ™re getting off track.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I think youвЂ™re right. JulianвЂ™s such a shit. Just like his mother. Remember? I idolized her, but she was busy idolizing electricians and grips.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: She idolized everyone, Mick.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Ecumenicalism is a noble ideal.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (with staged anger) Ecumenicalism??? My best friend is telling me that my ex-wife was sleeping with everyone, and all these years he never said a word! Do you get how serious this is?  36.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: And you never told me about Gilda Black.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Ok, I get it. Now that youвЂ™ve had your little revenge, can we be serious? IвЂ™m going to call that shithead son of mine. Mick grabs the phone again and dials.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? You really think you can convince him to get back together with Lena? ItвЂ™s hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: No, but I want to at least know what happened. His son must have said вЂњhelloвЂќ on the other end of th because Mick starts in on him, his tone severe. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Julian, this is your father, even though at this point, based on the evidence, IвЂ™m not so sure you are my son. The intellectual screenwriter gestures to the shy one to notes.

dialogues.speaker: INTELLECTUAL SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Take notes. We can use this in the film.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. HOTEL. DAY
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s late for breakfast. Some of the waiters are alread setting up for lunch. The only guests at this hour are the eternally silent cou They finish their breakfast, then get up and leave, maintaining their strict silence the whole while. Mick and Fred follow them with their eyes, and when they disappear from view, Mick, with a mechanical gesture, han Fred fifty Swiss francs.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: How are you always so sure theyвЂ™re not going to speak?  37.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Because I know something about them, the waiter told me.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I canвЂ™t tell you, itвЂ™s my advantage over you.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Tell me right this minute. Besides, I can always get the waiter to tell me too, a little bribe... IвЂ™ve thrown so much money away over this story already...

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Alright then, IвЂ™11 tell you: theyвЂ™re mute. Mick starts.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: You little shit! Give me back my money, all of it. YouвЂ™re a cheat. All bets are off.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You are so gullible! I was joking, Mick, theyвЂ™re not mute. Their conversation is interrupted by a silent apparition the far end of the dining room: a forty-year-old man, impeccably dressed in jacket and tie, followed by a plump woman who is, by all appearances, his secretary, an anony looking woman of about forty, unkempt, hair pulled back a old way, no makeup, decent but inexpensive clothes. Mick and Fred glare at the man who makes his way toward t Without even looking at her, he hands his secretary his c phone, and she slips it into a menвЂ™s leather briefcase. They cross the dining room together. The man stops at Fre and Mick's table. The secretary keeps a few feet back and starts fiddling with her phone, checking e-mails. Mick looks at the man. By now itвЂ™s clear that this is h Julian. Stunningly handsome, classic good looks, perfect. Confident and proud, Julian holds his fatherвЂ™s gaze. Fr eyes ping-pong from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?  38.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s really rather banal, dad. I fell in love with another woman.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Who's all of eighteen, right?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: No dad, sheвЂ™s not eighteen. SheвЂ™s thirty. A reasonable age.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Well, however old she is, youвЂ™ve really fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s your opinion.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Yes, that is my opinion. Lena is an extraordinary woman. At this point I realize, of course, that sheвЂ™s wasted on you. SheвЂ™s far too intelligent for you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Perhaps. But why did you make me come? IвЂ™m not about to change my mind.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s what everyone says, at first. Then they end up begging their spouse to take them back. I canвЂ™t tell you how many times IвЂ™ve seen it...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Mom left you and she never begged you to take her back.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (to Fred) What did I tell you? You see now where he gets it from, this asshole?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: So in your opinion, a manвЂ™s an asshole because, even if he didnвЂ™t want to, even if he tried like crazy to stay with his wife, even if he booked them a dream vacation, he realizes he just canвЂ™t go through with it because he has fallen hopelessly in love with another woman?  39.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Just like your mother! Melodramatic, hyperbolic, and completely idiotic.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (explodes) Well then, are we allowed to know who this whore you've fallen in love with is?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Me. Fred and Mick go white. They lean forward. WeвЂ™d nearly forgotten about the nondescript secretary standing behind Julian, but it was she who spoke. She takes a step forwar and reaffirms in a dignified manner:

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I am the woman Julian has lost his head for. WeвЂ™re getting married as soon as his divorce is finalized.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Precisely. Fred's and MickвЂ™s jaws drop. Stunned in disbelief, they gape at her, at a loss for words. The woman stands close to Julian. They put their arms aro each other. He is gorgeous, as handsome as George Clooney She just the opposite.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: My name is Paloma Faith. And IвЂ™m not a whore. IвЂ™m a singer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (proud) We work together. I'm producing her next album. Mick recovers a grain of sense and says:

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss, but could you leave us alone for a moment? My sonвЂ™s father-in-law and I need to have a word in private with Julian.  40.

dialogues.speaker: PALOMA FAITH
dialogues.text: Okay, but not for long. We can't stand being apart from each other for more than five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Very kind of you, dear, but don't worry, I'll only need a minute to fathom my son's psychology. The woman walks away, her gait ackward and ungainly. Fred and Mick follow her with their eyes and wait until s has left the dining room before they turn to meet Julianв proud, impassive gaze. Mick seems sincere now. He truly wants to fathom the myst of the human condition. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Forgive me, Julian, but IвЂ™m trying to understand. It may be banal, and maybe IвЂ™m too old to understand, but you have to explain something to me: Lena is a beautiful woman, a dream. And this one here is the most insignificant woman on the face of the planet. In short, I mean, but you, what the fuck do you see in her? Julian is ill at ease for the first time. He sighs, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Yes, Julian, I really want to know. Julian takes his time. He checks to make sure his secreta is not in the room, then turns and looks at his father an says all in one breath:

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: She's really good in bed. Mick and Fred are really at a loss for words now.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY LANE. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred and Lena walk through that beautiful valley. Proud and serious, she stares into the distance.  4l. He is ill at ease and doesnвЂ™t know what to say. HeвЂ™s distracted by the sound of a bird that suddenly starts to sing when Lena calls him back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: So who is this bitch?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Somebody by the name of Paloma Faith.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: And what does she do?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: The most obscene thing in the world.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: She's a prostitute?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Worse. SheвЂ™s a pop star.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: And what did Julian say?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I already told you.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Not really. All you did was babble incomprehensibly.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Julian was the one who was babbling. HeвЂ™s not all there in the head.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: It doesnвЂ™t seem that way to me. He must have made twenty decisions in two hours. He moved out. He rented an apartment. He spoke with a divorce lawyer. That doesnвЂ™t seem like a confused man to me. You keep telling me this woman is ugly and insignificant, so what does he see in her that he didnвЂ™t in me?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: You told me Mick asked him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Did I?  42.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Yes, thatвЂ™s what you said. So what was JulianвЂ™s response?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You know, Lena, I donвЂ™t remember.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: You're really pissing me off, daddy. You remember perfectly well, and youвЂ™re hopeless at telling lies. What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I really donвЂ™t remember, I swear. He must have mumbled something idiotic.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: If you donвЂ™t tell me, I swear I'll scream right here and now. What did he say? What the fuck does this woman have - at least according to Julian - that I donвЂ™t? I want to know what he said! I want to know. Fred stops. He canвЂ™t stand it any more. He sighs deeply decides to tell her what she wants to know.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: He said sheвЂ™s good in bed. Lena turns to stone. Her face tightens, sours nastily. Wi savage coldness, she says to her father.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: You didnвЂ™t have to tell me. And she storms off, leaving her father alone in the middl the valley as the two notes the little boy had played ret not on a violin now, but on a gloomy double bass.

dialogues.speaker: 21A/1
dialogues.text: Those two gloomy notes hover in the steam of the Turkish baths and saunas, where backlit, naked bodies of all ages look lifeless, abandoned to the heat and sweat. Toned, gleaming bodies, ample, round bodies, old, worn-ou bodies. This is the work of wellness. This is how some pe try to prolong the future or awkwardly pursue a youthful past.

dialogues.speaker: 21A/2 21A/3
dialogues.text: And then, more bodies, eyes closed, buried in tubs, wrapp in herbs and mud. Like living meadows.  43. Motionless still lifes, while the double bass plays discreetly, without ever moving away from those two simpl notes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MASSAGE ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Candles, incense, shadows. And the two double bass notes, to which is now added a sl variation. Fred and Lena are lying on their backs on marble benches. Naked, but completely covered in dark mud. They look like theyвЂ™ve been petrified in some volcanic eruption. Their eyes are the only part of them not covere mud. They stare lifelessly at the ceiling, on which a sof and hypnotic light plays. Fred, rather awkwardly, is trying to be fatherly.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Believe me, Lena, I can understand you, really, I can. Silence. Lena doesnвЂ™t respond. But when she does, she i lucid, furious, and ruthless.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: You can understand me, Daddy? Like hell you can! Mummy would have been able to understand me. Mummy found herself with you in the same situation I'm in now, not once but dozens of times. And she always pretended not to know. You had a stream of women, but she just kept going. Not just for us children, but also, above all, for you. She loved you and so she forgave you. No matter what happened, she still wanted to be with you. But who were you? Who? ThatвЂ™s what I always asked myself. You never gave anything, not to her, not to me, nothing. You gave everything to your music. Music, music, music! There was nothing else in your life. Only music. And aridness. Never a caress, never a hug, a kiss, nothing. You never knew anything about your children. You never knew if we were suffering, if we were happy. Nothing. Everything was on mummyвЂ™s shoulders. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At home, all youвЂ™d ever say to her were two words: вЂњQuiet, Melanie.вЂќ And mummy would explain to us, вЂњQuiet, daddyвЂ™s composing,вЂќ вЂњQuiet, daddy's resting, he has a concert tonight,вЂќ вЂњQuiet, daddy is talking on the phone with someone important.вЂќ вЂњQuiet, daddy has Stravinsky coming to the house today.вЂќ You wanted to be Stravinsky, but you didn't have a single drop of his genius. "Quiet, Melanie!", was all you knew how to say. You never knew the first thing about my mother! You never bothered to take care of her. And even now, you havenвЂ™t brought her flowers for ten years. And then that letter! You think mummy never read it? Well, you're wrong. She found it and she read it. And I read it too. You probably donвЂ™t even remember that letter, but we do. The letter in which you declared your love for another man. Mummy had to endure that humiliation too. вЂњMy necessary experimentation in sexual matters,вЂќ as you put it. So your musical experimentation wasnвЂ™t enough for you, you had to experiment with homosexuality too! And you didnвЂ™t give a fuck about all the anguish you caused her. So donвЂ™t come telling me that you can understand, because you donвЂ™t understand a fucking thing. She's done. Silence. Fred doesnвЂ™t say a word. They just there, buried in mud, staring at the ceiling. The double bass notes are done as well.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL GYM. DAY
dialogues.text: One entire wall is set up for free climbing. The hippy mountaineer is at the top of the wall, thirty f up, hanging by one hand, dangling in the air without a sa rope, with an admirable casualness. He addresses that pale, thirteen-year-old girl we saw earlier. She stands down below, near the base of the wall She hasn't even climbed an inch. The mountaineer speaks sweetly from up above.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAINEER
dialogues.text: Come on, Frances, give it a try. The girl looks up at him but doesnвЂ™t say a word. SheвЂ™ biting her nails. MOUNTAINEER (CONTвЂ™D) WouldnвЂ™t you like to come see what the world looks like from up here? The girl looks at him and nods. MOUNTAINEER (CONTвЂ™D) Good, now give it a go. The girl shakes her head no. MOUNTAINEER (CONTвЂ™D) Ok, wait there. In three swift moves, the mountaineer is back at her side MOUNTAINEER (CONTвЂ™D) Climb on my shoulders. The girl gets onto his huge shoulders. He starts climbing confidently, easily, as if he were carrying a knapsack instead of a human being. MOUNTAINEER (CONTвЂ™D) Ok, now, as we climb, look down. See how beautiful the world is from up here? The girl, clinging to his shoulders, turns and looks down And from high up on the wall she spots someone standing a the door to the gym, looking up at them. ItвЂ™s Lena. So the girl вЂњknocksвЂќ on the mountaineerвЂ™s shoulder, him to turn. He looks down, but LenaвЂ™s not there. She h already disappeared. 24. EXT./INT. HOTEL GARDEN/MASSEUSEвЂ™S ROOM. DAY We're in a different garden now, more isolated, further a from the hotel, one that abuts the building where the sta lives. Guests never come here. The main hotel seems far a In the center of the garden are abundant rose bushes, fountains, even a fake little stream. All laid out - rath clumsily - to resemble a lush, lyrical garden of Eden. As we said, thereвЂ™s no one here. No, wait - thereвЂ™s F HeвЂ™s sitting on a bench staring at the fake little stre sucking on a candy. His eyes are so laden with melancholy would be impossible for them to look any sadder. He seems dazed, absent, lost in thought.  46. All of a sudden he rouses himself. He blows his nose, qui rubs the tip four times with his handkerchief, folds it, puts it back in his pocket. As he puts his handkerchief away, his eye is drawn to something in a ground-floor window: his tiny, timid masse in shorts and a T-shirt, is dancing, moving gracefully in front of a TV. SheвЂ™s playing a Kinect game. A stylized figurine on the TV screen demonstrates the moves for her. ItвЂ™s marvelous and moving to see this petite girl dance with such incongruous intensity. SheвЂ™s all sweaty, her plastered to her forehead and temples. Fred watches her while his hand instinctively, rhythmical rubs a candy wrapper. Fred doesnвЂ™t notice that thereвЂ™s another man there, b him, wrapped in a white robe. HeвЂ™s watching the girl da too. ItвЂ™s Jimmy Tree, the American actor.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL RESTAURANT. EVENING
dialogues.text: Lots of people at dinner. Still that cavernous silence. Fred and Mick stare at the silent German couple, in match tonalities today too, a blue theme this time. Lena enters the dining room. She has abandoned her simple sober look and is wearing a highly provocative dress and a new, very flattering hairstyle. A wave of nostalgia floods MickвЂ™s heart.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: You remind me of Brenda Morel when she was thirty. When she made "At James' house" with me. You should dress this way all the time, Lena.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: From now on that's exactly what IвЂ™m going to do. Fred follows Lena with her eyes, but she deliberately avo looking at him and takes her seat at the table. The mountaineer, seated at another table, canвЂ™t help bu notice how beautiful Lena is. His eyes light up, but then grow dull again, as if heвЂ™s been defeated even before h begins. Dejected, he puts down his spoon and stops eating Mark Kozelek and his other friends have joined Jimmy at h table. TheyвЂ™re all talking, in groups of two, all excep Jimmy. HeвЂ™s fixated on the mountaineer and Lena, and do miss a thing of what is unfolding between them.  47. Then, all of a sudden, something unbelievable happens. The German woman gets up calmly and slaps her husband so he nearly falls out of his chair. It goes without saying that everyone turns and gapes in astonishment. The woman walks out of the dining room in the most dignif manner imaginable. MickвЂ™s, Fred's and LenaвЂ™s jaws drop. Stunned, they fo whole thing. Everyone at Jimmy Tree's table starts snickering. All but Jimmy, that is. He too follows the scene open-mouthed. The slapped husband seems indifferent to their stares. He simply returns to his meal, calmly eating his cream of mushroom soup. The obese South American, supported by his wife, gets up his table and slowly makes his way toward the dining room door. But when he gets to the table of the slapped husban he stops. The elderly German lifts his eyes to the obese South American, who does two things: first he smiles slightly, and then he caresses the GermanвЂ™s cheek with pudgy hand. The elderly man looks at him gratefully, and tries to return the smile. The South American walks away the deadly silence that has descended over the room. The camera finds Jimmy Tree. He has followed everything, naturally, and is really moved.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: One of those little stages has been set up in the garden, opposite the pool. A local singer - an elegant woman, abo fifty years old - is performing, accompanied by three musicians. The hotel guests are scattered about on lawn furniture, enjoying the beautiful concert. Fred, Mick, and Lena are at one table, listening to the singer's splendid rendition of вЂњLili Marleen.вЂќ Jimmy Tree stands and listens too, completely enraptured. serious, concentrated look on his face, he whispers the German lyrics, which he knows by heart. Then he senses a presence to his left. Jimmy turns. The silent German woman is looking at him, her hand extended, if inviting him to dance.
