He smiles at her and steps clos They begin to dance slowly.  48. The German womanвЂ™s husband, sitting at a table, is a bu of anger, he is devoured by jealousy. Fred and Mick are dying of curiosity. They stare at Jimmy the woman as they dance. Jimmy murmurs something in her ear, not trying to be seductive though.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What lovely perfume youвЂ™re wearing... What is it? Mick and Fred wait for the woman to speak. The German woman, embarrassed, doesnвЂ™t respond, but hol a little tighter. Jimmy holds her tighter too and, as he dances, he lets himself go, closing his eyes. From their table, Kozelek and his friends stare intently Jimmy. The hippy mountaineer pretends rather awkwardly that he j happens to be passing by, but itвЂ™s clear that he is tak tortuous path in order to look at Lena. She doesnвЂ™t eve notice him. He is so overcome with emotion that, despite being an expert climber, he trips on a table leg, but doe fall. вЂњLili MarleenвЂќ is over. The German woman smiles at Ji he smiles back. They move apart. She returns to her husbandвЂ™s table. He glares ferocious her. She feels his eyes on her but avoids his gaze. Jimmy approaches Fred carrying a herbal tea. He sits down next to him. Their smiles convey a shared warmth.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Is that straight herbal tea or is it mixed with a gin and tonic?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Straight tea. I'm trying to be good. Fred smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Too bad! He blows his nose in his usual manner. Jimmy observes him FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) HowвЂ™s the work on your character going?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: So so... pretty well, actually. IвЂ™ve come up with some interesting details.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: This morning, that girl dancing all by herself. I saw her too. It was... it was....

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ... unforgettable.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Yes. ThatвЂ™s exactly the word: unforgettable. Jimmy finishes his herbal tea and takes his leave with a playful military salute. Fred smiles at him. But Lena wip the smile off his face when she says.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Maybe the problem is that Julian and I never had children. Fred turns and looks at her. Serious now.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know what the problem is. IвЂ™m not going to try and cheer you up by telling you lies or talking about things IвЂ™ve never understood. You're right: all I understand is music. And do you know why? Because music doesnвЂ™t need words or experience to be understood. It just is. Your mother would have understood you. I canвЂ™t. But your mother's not here. They look at each other without saying another word.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL RESTAURANT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The elegant woman who sang "Lili Marleen" is the only per in the otherwise deserted restaurant. Wearing an evening and showing us her ancient and noble profile, she is sitt at one of the tables. Eyes lowered, with the concentratio a starving animal, she devours a chicken leg with her han Suddenly she stops eating and looks up, gazing vacantly i space. A fixed, sterile stare. At that very moment a vers she had sung from "Lili Marleen" echoes in her head, a cappella. She lowers her eyes to the chicken leg and the stops. She starts eating again, as voracious as before.  50.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s late. The garden where the little concerts are hel deserted. Only Fred Ballinger is still there. He has fall asleep in a chair, as in the opening scene of the film. T lights are low and the wind is blowing. Fred opens his ey and sees that a dozen rocking chairs, scattered around th garden, are moving in unison in the wind. Everything else still.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The deserted lobby. Only one person is there, sitting on couch: the young and eternally ungainly hooker. Mick Boyle crosses the deserted lobby on the way to his r His eyes fall on the chubby girl. She gives him an awkward but alluring, knowing look. He smiles at her, but with the smile of a father, which s like a tender refusal. He walks away. The girl looks sad and serious again. But after a few steps Mick stops, as if heвЂ™s had second thoughts. The girl realizes this, but she deliberately keeps from looking at him again. Mick turns and observes her from afar. He is serious. And tempted. He reflects. He stares at the girl. She decides to look at him now, but itвЂ™s too late: Mick already gone. 27. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT Fred and Lena are asleep in the double bed. Then, through the windows, a theatrical light slowly come on, illuminating ten women on the balcony, all dressed in black. Somber, immobile. Slowly, slowly, the violin starts up again, playing those same first notes of вЂњSimple Song No.3.вЂќ The women on the balcony join in with the violin and begi sing in the most splendid soprano voices. Fred opens his eyes and says.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Enough.  51. Then, all of a sudden, as if he were possessed, he throws the covers and hurls himself at the window. But thereвЂ™s no one there. The balcony is empty and dark shouts and punches the glass. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Enough! Stop singing, now! Enough! Lena wakes up with a start. She is worried.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Daddy, stop, thatвЂ™s enough! You were dreaming. Fred composes himself. He stops shouting, but still cling the glass, in a daze. Lena looks behind him, now sheвЂ™s one who doesnвЂ™t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY LANE. DAY
dialogues.text: Parachutists twirl gracefully, silently just below the cr mountain peaks. Fred and Mick are taking a walk. Out of nowhere, a little dramatically, as if choosing a t at random, Fred says.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: This morning I took a long, powerful piss. And while I was doing it, I was thinking, Jesus, when is this going to stop? When? I just kept pissing and pissing. And I was so happy! I havenвЂ™t been that happy in months. Mick hides his displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Good, IвЂ™m happy for you. But Fred realizes his friend is upset.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I was joking, Mick. It didnвЂ™t happen like that.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t joke about these things, Fred. Prostate is serious.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You always fall for my jokes. You've been believing every word I say for the last sixty years.  52.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I invent stories, Fred. I have to believe everything in order to make things up. Do you remember the other day? When you told me you donвЂ™t remember your parents any more?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, I donвЂ™t remember.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Of course you do. Well, you made me realize that not only do I not remember my parents, but my childhood, for example, I donвЂ™t remember a thing about it. ThereвЂ™s only one thing I still remember.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s that?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: The precise moment when I learned to ride a bicycle. I know it sounds banal, but oh, what joy! It was sheer joy. And this morning, as if by magic, for the first time, I also remembered the moment right after I learned to ride a bike.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: The moment in which you fell.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: How the fuck did you know?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Because thatвЂ™s how it was for everyone, Mick. You learn to do something, you're really happy, and then you forget to brake.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Isn't that a terrific metaphor for life?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s not go rushing to conclusions, Mick. And then something amazing happens. A boy, about eleven y old, comes toward them on the country lane. HeвЂ™s riding mountain bike, and, with astonishing self-confidence, is doing a wheelie. Mick and Fred watch him, speechless. The peddles past them, still up on one wheel. He races all th way to the end of the lane, as silent as a ghost, balance one wheel.  53. Mick and Fred turn to watch him, ecstatic. Fred thinks for a minute, then says: FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) You know something, Mick?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You and me, weвЂ™re never going to die. Mick turns to his friend. He smiles and then adds:

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Now letвЂ™s not go rushing to conclusions, Fred! But then something catches his attention: the silent Germ couple, dressed in matching green, is about to enter the dense woods. Mick gestures to Fred, who turns and sees th too, right as they disappear among the trees. Fred doesnв need to think twice. He turns to Mick and in a serious vo says:

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s follow them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred and Mick crouch behind some bushes, perfectly still. Watching. And what do they see? They see the silent German couple leaning against a tree, their clothes half off. He is penetrating her with a pass worthy of an teenage boy dying to screw. They are really enjoying it. He is in a frenzy, sheвЂ™s a to climax. They come, both of them, together. The myth of simultaneous orgasm, right there in the woods. They moan pleasure. So in their own way, they have spoken. Impassive, Fred merely takes out his wallet and hands Mic fifty Swiss francs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred walks down the hallway. Lena is waiting for him at t door to their suite. She seems restless, short of breath, anxious to talk with her father. In fact, she says to him right away.  54.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Where have you been, daddy? This manвЂ™s been here for an hour, he says heвЂ™s Queen Elizabeth's emissary. Fred snorts, as if this was the last thing he wanted to h

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told him to make himself comfortable in the living room. 31. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. DAY Lena pours a coffee for the QueenвЂ™s emissary, whom we m earlier. He and Fred sit facing each other, one on a love seat, the other in an easy chair, a small table between t Lena goes and sits on a chair behind her father. The emissary nervously taps his pantsвЂ™ pocket, where we see clearly the bulge of a packet of cigarettes. Fred not his agitation.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You can smoke here, if you want. The emissary canвЂ™t believe his ears. HeвЂ™s as astounde thereвЂ™d just been an earthquake. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: The hotel manager is a music lover. So he grants me some small privileges. The emissaryвЂ™s smile is one of infinite gratitude. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY You have no idea how much pleasure this gives me.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Are you feeling tense? QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY IвЂ™ll say. He says, taking a deep, restorative drag on his cigarette

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: ThereвЂ™s no ashtray, though. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY That's fine, IвЂ™1l cope.  55.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t have much time, so letвЂ™s skip the formalities. I have to do a thorough cleansing of my intestines soon. The emissaryвЂ™s expression instinctively looks pained an says. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY Will it hurt?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, it's just embarrassing. The emissary sighs and starts in. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY I wasnвЂ™t able to convince the Queen. I relayed your reticence about the songs to her. I proposed an alternative repertoire. An alternative musician. An alternative sort of evening. She doesnвЂ™t want alternatives. She wants you and only you and only your вЂњSimple Songs.вЂќ She says itвЂ™s all that Prince Philip listens to.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry. I donвЂ™t want to seem rude. But IвЂ™m afraid itвЂ™s impossible. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY But why?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I explained why, the last time we met. Personal reasons. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY And is there no way to resolve these personal reasons?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Unfortunately not. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY IвЂ™m begging you, Maestro. I have a difficult job. I simply must return to London with a positive answer.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: But my answer is negative. Lena follows every word.  56. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY I simply donвЂ™t understand. What is it that doesnвЂ™t work? The date? The location? The orchestra? The soprano? The Queen?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Please, donвЂ™t insist. Personal reasons. The emissary drops his diplomatic demeanor and shows a fl of anger. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY And what exactly are these bloody personal reasons? Fred doesnвЂ™t respond. Lena is beginning to understand. We're not, but she is. S starts to cry quietly, inwardly.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Personal means that IвЂ™m not obliged to explain them. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY LetвЂ™s see if we can resolve these personal problems then. What is it that is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (at random) The soprano. The emissary beams. He thinks they have arrived at a solution. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY We'll get a different one, then, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: It wouldnвЂ™t make any difference. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY Even though Sumi Jo is the absolute best, and she has already expressed her enthusiasm at being directed by you. SheвЂ™s ecstatic! In seventh heaven!

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not interested. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY What is it you have against her?  57.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Nothing! I donвЂ™t even know her. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY And so?! Fred loses his patience for the first time. He raises his voice, practically shouts.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: So enough already! Lena cries more openly now, her eyes brimming with tears. She tries to hide them, but she canвЂ™t. The emissary notices LenaвЂ™s tears and is dumbfounded. H trying to understand, but doesnвЂ™t know what to say. He open his arms in defeat. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY I just do not understand. What exactly is the problem? Fred shouts at him again. His words come tumbling out, unplanned.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: The problem is that those Simple Songs were composed for my wife. And only my wife performed them, only my wife recorded them. And as long as I live, my wife will be the only one to sing them. The problem, my dear sir, is that my wife canвЂ™t sing any more. Now do you understand? Do you? Lena has buried her face in her hands, trying to stifle h sobs. Fred is beside himself. He looks exhausted, drained. The emissary is struck dumb. He gets to his feet and stub out his cigarette in the pack. He is deeply dismayed. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY Yes, I do understand now, and I beg your pardon. Maestro. He walks quickly to the door. Fred and Lena just sit there, he staring into space and s weeping behind him.  58. 31A. INT/EXT. CORRIDOR + HOTEL BRIDGE. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: 31A/1
dialogues.text: In close-up, the bells in the corridors trill merrily.

dialogues.speaker: 31A/2

dialogues.speaker: INT. MASSAGE ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: The young masseuse is rubbing oil on her hands. Fred Ballinger, lying on his stomach on the massage table his head stuck in the hole, looks down at the floor, righ the girlвЂ™s tiny sandals. The masseuse places her hands gently on FredвЂ™s naked ba She begins massaging him, but stops after a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MASSEUSE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m going to give you a different type of massage, because you are stressed. No, to be precise, you're not stressed, you're emotional.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You understand everything with your hands.

dialogues.speaker: MASSEUSE
dialogues.text: We can understand all sorts of things by touching. Who knows why people are so afraid of touching.

dialogues.text: Maybe because they think it has something to do with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: MASSEUSE
dialogues.text: Which is another good reason for touching instead of talking. Fred is silent. He stares at the floor for a while. Then says:

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t you like to talk?

dialogues.speaker: MASSEUSE
dialogues.text: (frank) I never have anything to say.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: We forget sometimes, but sincerity is beautiful, isnвЂ™t it?  59. But the masseuse has changed the kind of massage she is doing. She has nothing more to say, so she doesnвЂ™t say anything. Fred relaxes and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOUNTAIN PEAK. DAY
dialogues.text: Mick and his young screenwriters are climbing up a steep mountain path. They meet a young family coming down the mountain. The fa is wearing a toddler backpack carrier, in which his three year-old son is sleeping peacefully. Mick looks at the sleeping child. Dressed for trekking, Mick and his young screenwriters ar ascending an impassable mountain trail. They reach the su - what a view! We can sense that suspended silence, the clean, crisp air, and appreciate the magnificent panorama the mountains and the valley below. There is a telescope at the lookout point, one of those tourist ones you have to put a coin in to make it work. They admire the panorama in silence. Mick breaks away fro the group and puts a coin in the telescope. Then he calls young screenwriters over.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Come look. The girl goes first. She peers into the telescope. Mick instructs her as the others listen in. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Now listen. Do you see that mountain over there?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah, it seems really close.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Exactly. ThatвЂ™s what you see when you're young. Everything seems really close. ThatвЂ™s the future. Now come with me. She takes the girl by the hand and invites her to look through the telescope from the other direction. The girl looks from the other side and sees the faces of friends. They look really far away even though theyвЂ™re six feet away from her.  60. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) And this is what you see when you're old. Everything seems really far away. ThatвЂ™s the past. The girl looking in the telescope is moved. HeвЂ™s too fa in the inverted lens, so she canвЂ™t see that the boy she always fighting with is moved as well. TheyвЂ™re all at a loss for words. Mick crouches over a knapsack and pulls out a bottle of spumante and some plastic cups, talking all the while. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) When I was young, I used to say to myself: if I grow old IвЂ™m not going to make the same mistake all old people make, IвЂ™m not going to become boring and pedantic. But thatвЂ™s exactly what I have become. So, forgive me. Now for the serious stuff: Brenda canвЂ™t wait to get started. And I am so proud of having written this screenplay with you. I have to confess something. IвЂ™ve made twenty films, but theyвЂ™re all irrelevant. This is the only film that means anything to me. This film has... yes, well, itвЂ™s my sentimental, intellectual, and moral testament. This film is the only thing that matters to me. Nothing else. And so, letвЂ™s toast to the completion of the third draft of вЂњLifeвЂ™s Last Day.вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: SCREENWRITER 1

Side by side, their shoulders resting against the edge of pool, they let themselves be cradled by the powerful jet water hitting their backs. dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Hello, Fred Ballinger.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you that I checked at the front desk, and you really are Fred Ballinger.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Good, IвЂ™m glad you set your mind to rest on that score. Jimmy Tree smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: ThereвЂ™s something else I wanted to tell you too.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Go right ahead.

The hippy mountaineer, all excited, is facing her. He too only a towel. With his hairy shoulders, hairy chest, shag beard, and long hair, he looks like a giant bear, like so large, peaceful beast. Lena keeps her eyes closed. The mountaineer canвЂ™t take kindly eyes off of her. He swallows, musters his courage, starts to say something changes his mind, too timid to speak, then tries again. dialogues.text: IвЂ™m Luca. Luca Moroder. Embarrassed, he lets out a moronic laugh that sounds like thunderclap. Lena opens her eyes, expressionless, and simply says:

MOUNTAINEER (CONTвЂ™D) This is a Forerunner 620, it has a color touch display, it estimates vo2max values - the maximum rate of oxygen consumption during maximum exertion. I'd like to give it to my cousin for Christmas. We always go climbing together. He was supposed to be here too, but he slipped in the bathtub and broke his femur. Lena smiles politely.

dialogues.text: Fred, Mick, and Jimmy Tree, in white robes, are sunning peacefully on chaise lounges. Eyes closed. Fred has a newspaper open on his lap. Mick and Jimmy are chatting.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: So whoвЂ™s the most talented actress you've ever worked with, Mr. Boyle?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Brenda Morel. Without a doubt. A genius. She canвЂ™t have read more than two books her whole life, and one of them was her autobiography, written by a ghost writer naturally, but still, BrendaвЂ™s a genius. Jimmy chuckles.
