dialogues.text: A genius in what sense?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: If you know how to steal, you donвЂ™t need training. Stealing becomes your education. ThatвЂ™s how Brenda is. Even when, thanks to my films, sheвЂ™d become a diva, she never forgot where she came from, her home was really the street. And thatвЂ™s where she stayed, on the street, stealing everything. Everything. Which is how she created such unforgettable characters. And won two Oscars.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What would she steal?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: We were filming вЂњThe Crystal Woman.вЂќ And in the middle of a scene, an electrician walks by, toward the back of the set. HeвЂ™s got this limp, real slight. Whenever he steps with his shorter leg, it makes a noise, real faint though, barely noticeable. No one even hears it, no one but Brenda, that is. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s reciting her lines and all of a sudden she yells вЂњstop.вЂќ So I yell back, вЂњWhat the fuck are you doing, Brenda? Only I can say stop.вЂќ вЂњFuck that, Mick,вЂќ she says to me, вЂњif my character is wrong, then IвЂ™1l say stop.вЂќ She looks at the electrician. HeвЂ™s dying, but Brenda lights up and says, вЂњMick, my character has to have one leg shorter than the other. She limps.вЂќ I practically fall off my chair. вЂњAre you out of your mind, Brenda?вЂќ I say to her. вЂњYour character canвЂ™t limp. Your character is the most desirable woman in the whole world, every man on the planet wants to get her into bed, sheвЂ™s a dream.вЂќ And you know what she says? She says to me, вЂњEven dreams have their problems, Mick.вЂќ Jimmy laughs. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) And she was right. That little limp won her her second Oscar. A muffled, intermittent sound, which at first only Fred hears, makes him open his eyes. But the sun is shining ri in them, so all he can see is a small black circle that r up to the sky and then falls again. The sound, and then t black circle again. ItвЂ™s enough to make Fred want to get up and take a look Curious, he shuffles toward the tennis court, and Jimmy T and Mick Boyle decide to go with him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TENNIS COURT. DAY
dialogues.text: At the tennis court, Fred, Mick, and Jimmy are struck dum what they see. That obese South American is doing something out of this world: with his left foot he sends a tennis ball flying h in the air, and when it comes down, he kicks it up again, without ever letting it touch the ground, sending it sixt seventy feet in the air. The tennis ball against the blue sky. It falls, he kicks it again, with a naturalness - despite the inhuman effort it takes for that massive body move - that sparks admiration and horror at the same time Mick, Jimmy, and Fred canвЂ™t believe their eyes. Rightly After five or six feats of such amazing acrobatics, he st completely exhausted. He has trouble catching his breath.  66. Jimmy spots his briarwood cane, leaning against the fence grabs it and rushes over with it. The South American thanks him, eyes brimming with gratitu body dripping with sweat. Without saying a word, he slowl walks away, leaning heavily on his cane. Two guitar notes, melancholy and discreet, accompany the South AmericanвЂ™s broken, belabored gait. Jimmy, Fred, and Mick just stand there, scattered around tennis court, and watch the best ex-soccer player in the world leave the field. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: The two guitar notes float in here, without developing further. A flowered wall, English style. In front of it is a small table with a magnificent silver tea service. A womenвЂ™s purse, flung by who knows whom, crashes into tea set. Everything ends up on the floor. The purse tumbl open. ItвЂ™s empty. After a moment, the Queen's emissary enters the frame. He very distraught. He says in a whisper. QUEENвЂ™S EMISSARY Your Majesty, you nearly hit me! QUEEN ELIZABETHвЂ™S VOICE Yes, Mr. Bale, I nearly hit you. The devastated emissary sighs. ItвЂ™s as if the whole uni were going to hell in a handbag.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL RESTAURANT. EVENING
dialogues.text: The two guitar notes die softly during this scene. The German couple is silent again. They eat serenely, the eyes never meeting. The hippy mountaineer looks dejected, as if all his hopes have been dashed as he steals glances at Lena, sitting wi Fred and Mick. She doesnвЂ™t even notice him.  67. Jimmy Tree is dining with Mark Kozelek and other friends. They're laughing at Jimmy's perfect imitation of Marlon Brando. Sushi tonight. EveryoneвЂ™s using chopsticks. Fred, Mick, and Lena dine in silence. Lena says routinely.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: The French called again. They really want to do that book with you... your memoirs, everything about your work, your life. What shall I tell them?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (reflects) Tell them... He doesnвЂ™t know what else to say. Silence. Lena and Mic wait.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: To forget me! Tell them that. I'm retired! IвЂ™m done! With work and life. Mick raises his eyes heavenward, as if he knew this "song all too well and canвЂ™t stand it anymore. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) I have nothing to say, and whatвЂ™s more, I'm not interested.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Will you cut the crap? Your music conveyed surprising, new emotions.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: But emotions are overrated too, Mick. Mick throws his chopsticks onto the table. HeвЂ™s really off.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: You're really unbearable when you play the depressed cynic, Fred. ItвЂ™s a mystery how I managed to be your friend all these years.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You're a man of much patience, Mick.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And you're an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: That's for sure! Lena is about to say something but Mick cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: A book about your work, life your experiences - it would last forever. It would be a help to young musicians, to everyone. It's important...

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: (interrupts him) Important!... Preserve your memory for posterity, pass on your knowledge. I've been hearing the same old tune for years now, but itвЂ™s just an excuse, Mick, a way of ignoring the real problem.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And whatвЂ™s the real problem, Fred?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Death, Mick! Death, itвЂ™s so close.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: So, instead of living you're thinking about death coming closer. Even though youвЂ™re still alive. Mick nods vigorously. He addresses Lena.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Do you see why it pisses me off?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Yes, Lena sees.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: But doesnвЂ™t the idea of reliving your life, your work, fascinate you?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No. It only hurts me. CanвЂ™t you see that? And besides, there's nothing more to say. Stravinsky already said it all. He composed simple music and everyone attacked him. вЂњHeвЂ™s abandoned modernism! HeвЂ™s not respecting tradition!вЂќ the critics thundered. But he was merely rediscovering the past, his mirror. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s when he uttered that beautiful phrase: "You may respect, but I love." What more can I add? Lena and Mick have nothing else to say. Fred picks up his chopsticks and holds them in the air, not eating. Lena st at him. Out of the blue, the boy violinist comes over. Fred doesn even notice him. The child gently adjusts FredвЂ™s hand - the one holding chopsticks - raising it an inch. As if correcting his position. Fred gazes at the boy and smiles sadly. The boy simply smiles back at him, and then runs off, the children do. Always running, they are.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A fakir is lying on a bed of nails on the stage. Lena, Fred, Mick, and Jimmy Tree are sitting together at of the tables, impassively watching the show.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: These shows are really pathetic. All thatвЂ™s missing is a mime.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: We usually get one of those by the end of the summer as well. The fakir levitates, rising above the bed of nails. The audience applauds. The fakir's back is very red. He spits fire from his mout and says.

dialogues.speaker: FAKIR
dialogues.text: Thank you, everyone. And now, I hope you will enjoy some traditional horn music, played by a local ensemble. Eight old men carrying long horns come onto the stage. Th begin a gloomy litany. A man whom we assume to be the hotel manager comes over t our charactersвЂ™ table. He addresses Jimmy Tree, but Fre Mick, and Lena listen in as well.  70.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Tree, but a new guest has arrived. Her name is Joyce Owens, she has just won the Miss Universe pageant. SheвЂ™s a great admirer of yours and would like to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Ok, here I am. The manager gestures, and Miss Universe appears from a da corner of the garden. Our characters wait for her to arrive, their hearts aflut But Miss Universe turns out to be an unbelievable disappointment. SheвЂ™s wearing a cheap, oversize track s that ruins her figure and makes her look plump, and - eve though itвЂ™s dark - a pair of violet-tinted sunglasses w vulgar frames that are too big for her face. Her skin is her hair stringy and dirty. WhatвЂ™s more, she has an awf voice, which we hear when she shakes JimmyвЂ™s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s such a pleasure to meet you. IвЂ™m a huge fan of yours. I literally went crazy when you played Mister Q. Jimmy Tree raises his eyes heavenward. HeвЂ™s had more th enough of Mister Q. MISS UNIVERSE (CONTвЂ™D) I never miss a robot movie, but that oneвЂ™s my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: (teasing) Thank you. And do you ever watch any other kinds of movie, other than robot movies?

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: Of course! IвЂ™ve got my whole life ahead of me, and I want to be an actress. I don't want to just rely on my beauty.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: (chuckles) What else do you watch? Cartoons? Miss Universe stiffens a little.

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: Whatever I want.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Brava, Miss Universe!  71.

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: (now very serious) You know something, Mr. Tree?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: I appreciate irony, but when it is drenched in poison, it is drained of its force and reveals something else.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What does it reveal? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: Frustration. Yours, in this case, not mine.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: (leaning forward, nervous) I'm frustrated, Miss Universe?

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: I'm happy I took part in the Miss Universe pageant. Are you happy you played Mister Q? Jimmy Tree has no answer for her. Embarassment washes over the whole group. Jimmy extends a hand to Miss Universe, as if to acknowled defeat. But Miss Universe doesnвЂ™t shake it. She walks a Mick smooths his hair with the palm of his hand as Jimmy looks on. Watching Miss Universe as she quickly disappears, Mick, t break the chill that has descended...

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: How unbearable the insolent ostentation of youth is.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: In particular if the person listening is no longer young.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (laughing) That woman should be stabbed to death, I mean stabbed! Fred turns to look at Jimmy who has gone back to watching horn ensemble. And he says a touch of irony.  72.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: She's not at all stupid, Miss Universe. Jimmy, without looking at him, replies immediately.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Not at all! They both break out in big smiles. Lena watches Miss Universe walk across the garden, that peculiar look in her eye that women have when watching another woman. And when Miss Universe disappears from vie Lena does something: she turns ninety degrees and looks squarely at the mountaineer, who, naturally, is looking a her. His eyes are sparkling like never before. 41. EXT./INT. (MUSIC VIDEO) CAR. DAY. (The whole scene is shot and edited in the style of a mus video). Music so funky it would make a corpse dance:"Can't rely o you." A luxury car - a Maserati - races along a sun-kissed moun road. Julian is driving. A splendidly made-up Paloma Fait appears in the backseat. She is the one who is singing. S wearing sexy lingerie and moving her body in the most sinuous, sensual manner. A totally different Paloma from dull, anonymous woman we saw earlier. She flicks her tong in Julian's ear and he howls with pleasure. Down on all fours, she moves like a panther in the back seat, upping eroticism with every gesture. Slithering like a snake, sh slips out the open window and climbs gracefully onto the roof, singing the whole time. She gets to her feet and da on top of the car, as sensual and sexy as before. The only reason she doesnвЂ™t fall off the roof of the mo car is because we are very clearly in the unreal world of music video. Julian leans out of the window and watches her from below turned on and moaning like a fool. He leans so far out of car trying to grab her that he has to hold the steering w with his foot. The car swerves, but thereвЂ™s no danger: weвЂ™re in a mu video. Julian climbs back into the driver's seat to avoid an accident. He fixes his eyes on the road, but is not for long: Palom now appears on the front windshield.  73. Slowly, she slithers down the windshield onto the hood. Pressing her body against the glass, she winks at him, ma eyes at him, shows him her tongue and everything else as rolls onto the hood, the car still tearing along at 120mp the wind in her hair. With an acrobatic move, Paloma finally climbs through the window again and is back in the car. She sits next to Julian. He wants to touch her, but she c prevents him, increasing his desire. SheвЂ™s been singing whole time, but now she pauses the song for a moment and says.

dialogues.speaker: PALOMA FAITH
dialogues.text: Now watch what I'm going to do for you! She opens the glove compartment and produces a sex toy th likes of which has never been seen before. A huge black rubber ball studded with menacing metal, luminescent stingers. ItвЂ™s impossible even to imagine w you could do with it. PALOMA FAITH (CONTвЂ™D) Watch this, honey. And the spiked, luminescent ball slowly disappears beneat her body, but just then...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Holy shit! 42. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT ... DARKNESS. A woman's scream shatters the music and everything else. Alarmed, Fred Ballinger switches on the lamp on the night stand. Lena awakens with a start, as if from a nightmare. She's sweating, panicked. She canвЂ™t breathe.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Lena, whatвЂ™s wrong? Lena is gasping for breath. She slowly comes back to real her breath returning to normal. She reassures her father.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing. It was just a dream.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: A nightmare?  74.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s say somewhere between the two. ItвЂ™s over now. Fred turns off the light. Half-light. Lena slowly settles down, but she canвЂ™t fall asleep. They have their backs each other. After a while she asks.

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a man, how did Miss Universe seem to you?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: An unbelievable disappointment. Lena is greatly cheered by her fatherвЂ™s remark. Then, a pause.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Daddy, I have to tell you something... personal.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Tell me, Lena.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Julian's an ass. Because IвЂ™m really good in bed.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: What do you mean... you know?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You're my daughter. And, in all modesty, I was a wonder between the sheets myself. Slowly but surely, once their embarrassment has faded, th start sniggering in the dark, each on his own side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CRAFT SHOP. DAY
dialogues.text: A shop full of souvenirs and local crafts made of wood. Fred roams around, glancing at the stuff on the shelves, without much interest. Jimmy Tree goes over to the cash register and - proud at having found it - presents a briarwood walking stick, ver similar to the one we saw the South American using. The s clerk starts wrapping it.  75. Jimmy is waiting when the pale, thirteen-year-old girl fr the hotel appears at his side. Pink circles around her ey making her seem not scary exactly, but vaguely pained. She bites her nails nervously as she stares at Jimmy, who senses her presence and so turns to her. She stares unabashed at him, long and hard enough to make Jimmy feel embarrassed, and then says confidently.

dialogues.speaker: PALE GIRL
dialogues.text: I saw you in a film once.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: So you liked Mister Q as well?

dialogues.speaker: PALE GIRL
dialogues.text: No, I saw you in that film where you play a father who never knew his son and meets him for the first time in a highway diner when the sonвЂ™s already fourteen. Jimmy turns to stone. He mutters.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: But nobody saw that movie!

dialogues.speaker: PALE GIRL
dialogues.text: There was a bit of dialog I really liked, when your son says, "Why weren't you a father to me?" and you say, "I didn't think I was up to it." At that moment I understood something really important.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PALE GIRL
dialogues.text: That no one in the whole world feels up to it. And so there's no reason to worry. Bye. See you at the hotel. And the girl walks away, her stride natural and easy. Jimmy just stands there, immobile, at the counter, starin into space. HeвЂ™s stunned. Instinctively, he puts on his sunglasses. Fred, standing still behind him among the shelves, must h heard everything, because he merely stares at Jimmy's bac He is as overcome as Jimmy is, and doesnвЂ™t say a word. just looks at back of the actor who is probably deeply mo right now.  76.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY LANE. DAY
dialogues.text: Jimmy and Fred walk along the beautiful lane that skirts mountain village. They walk in silence, wrapped in perfect sounds: cicadas distant cowbells.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What do you do all day, Fred?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: They tell me IвЂ™m apathetic. So I don't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t you miss your work?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Not at all. I worked far too much.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: So what do you miss?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: My wife. I miss my wife Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: I read on Wikipedia that you hung out with Stravinsky for a while when you were young.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What was he like?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: He was a very placid man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Placid? ThatвЂ™s all? Be generous with me, Fred. I need a generous friend. Tell me about Stravinsky.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: One day he said to me, вЂњIntellectuals donвЂ™t have any taste.вЂќ So from that day on, I did everything I could not to be an intellectual. And I succeeded. Jimmy doesnвЂ™t say anything. They walk on in silence. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) And you? What do you miss?  77.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Nothing, IвЂ™d say. Luckily.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Be generous with me, Jimmy. Jimmy smiles, as if caught red-handed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: What I missed I discovered four months ago reading Novalis. Fred is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You read Novalis?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: (playful) Even actors from California, when theyвЂ™re not getting drunk, snorting coke, or hanging out with anorexic models, occasionally read Novalis.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You're right, sorry. I'm an old man and full of prejudices. And what does Novalis say?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: "I'm always going home, always going to my father's house."

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARDEN HOTEL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mark Kozelek presses play on an iPod, and the sweet notes a synthesizer float out the speakers. ItвЂ™s a slow, hypn track. The camera moves slowly around the room; it takes Kozelek and Jimmy Tree's friends, who are listening seriously, attentively to the music. The camera glides ou onto the terrace and takes in Jimmy Tree, lying on a chai lounge and listening very intently to the music. He smoke cigarette, which he then puts out in a cup of herbal tea. Mark Kozelek comes out and joins him. He lies down on the chaise lounge next to JimmyвЂ™s.

dialogues.speaker: MARK KOZELEK
dialogues.text: How do you like it? I wrote it yesterday. ItвЂ™s called вЂњCeiling Gazing.вЂќ Jimmy listens and then says sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s fabulous, Mark.  78. On the track, MarkвЂ™s voice joins in and blends with the synthesizer. A voice so romantic it gives you the chills. 46. INT/EXT. REAR GARDEN HOTEL/ MASSEUSEвЂ™S ROOM. NIGHT The beautiful music continues, extra-diegetic now. ItвЂ™s really moving. Softly, as if in slow motion, the tiny, timid masseuse co into the cameraвЂ™s eye. In close-up now, sheвЂ™s dancing playing with Kinect again, but a different dance now. 47. INT./EXT. SOUTH AMERICANвЂ™S SUITE/REAR GARDEN HOTEL. The beautiful music can be heard here as well. The South American is on the terrace, in his underwear. H half-reclining on a chaise lounge. His wife is at the foo the lounge, massaging his massive, aching legs. He stares out across the valley. And then, suddenly, itвЂ like he has a vision. Bright lights come on, like the floodlights at a soccer stadium, and he sees twenty-two m divided into two rows of eleven. One row is wearing the Argentina national team jersey, and the other that of England. The twenty-two players clamber up the steep fiel and arrive at the hotel garden. They merge into a single and wave to a crowd that is not there. It seems like the up to an important soccer match. Overcome with emotion, the South American stares at this vision. His wife looks up at him sadly. She sees he is moved and in Spanish. SOUTH AMERICANвЂ™S WIFE What are you thinking about? The stadium floodlights suddenly go out.

dialogues.speaker: SOUTH AMERICAN
dialogues.text: The future. 48. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. NIGHT KozelekвЂ™s music dies down here. ItвЂ™s instrumental now makes it seem remote and discreet. Lena is asleep in the bed. Half-light. Fred is in the little living room, sitting in the middle the couch. From here he can see Lena asleep in the distan He looks away, and stares into space.  79. HeвЂ™s thinking, his thumb and index finger rubbing a can wrapper imperceptibly at irregular intervals, creating a beautiful, elementary melody. And that slight sound is what awakens Lena. She opens an Without moving, she studies her father from the bed as he sits motionless on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL RECEPTION. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The lights are dimmed for the night. Two concierges are checking in a group of six guests who have just arrived. TheyвЂ™re all about forty years old, four women and two m normal faces. But they have some unusual baggage: rigid m suitcases. Two other women arrive, wheeling metal racks f which hang dozens of outfits, covered in garment bags. They all seem really tired. KozelekвЂ™s music caresses th

dialogues.speaker: INT. SALINE GROTTO. NIGHT
dialogues.text: .-. and flows here. A fake underground grotto with papier-machГ© walls made t look like the Alps. A long spiral staircase in the center goes down and down, finishing right in a large round pool full of dark water so much salt that you can do the dead manвЂ™s float witho least effort. And in fact, Mick Boyle and his five screenwriters are floating naked on their backs in a studied darkness. They're brainstorming about the ending of вЂњLifeвЂ™s Las

dialogues.speaker: FUNNY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s on his deathbed, and murmurs to her, вЂњI should have devoted myself to you, and to our love, instead of wasting my life trying to become the king of insurance policies.вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: SCREENWRITER IN LOVE
dialogues.text: Or maybe he just says something banal to her, real simple, like вЂњTake care of yourself.вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: INTELLECTUAL SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: No, we have to stay with the physical pain right up to the end. How about if he says, вЂњNot even morphine can help me now.вЂќ  80.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: What if he focuses on some insignificant detail? If he said something like, вЂњI wonder whatever happened to that key ring you gave me twenty-five years ago, the one shaped like a horseshoe?вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: No. He doesnвЂ™t say anything on his deathbed. Silence on the part of the screenwriters. TheyвЂ™re waiti MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) SheвЂ™s the one who talks. Brenda. She says, вЂњI lost so much time because of you, Michael. I lost the best years of my life.вЂќ Silence. Then the shy screenwriter.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s lying on his deathbed, and she slaps him, just like that. An icy stare from Mick and the others. The shy screenwrit tries to make eat his words. SHY SCREENWRITER (CONTвЂ™D) I was just kidding!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL CORRIDOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: KozelekвЂ™s sweet music follows us here, in the stillness the hallway of this mountain hotel. The group of people w recently checked in are coming toward us, wheeling their metal racks and cumbersome metal suitcases. The group passes a room, the door slightly ajar, without noticing it. But the camera notices and peeks inside. On the bed sits elderly, bare-chested man, exhausted and sweaty. He stare the floor and drinks a glass of water. The unattractive, plump hooker is putting on her overcoat. She exits the ro and makes her way awkwardly and gracelessly to the elevat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ipod again, Mark KozelekвЂ™s music again, diegetic no A man gently combs JimmyвЂ™s hair and pulls it back, as J looks at himself in the mirror, a serious expression on h face. One of those dressing room mirrors, with all those little lights around it.  81. The hairdresser uses a razor to layer the hair on the bac Jimmy's head. He cuts it really short. A tense, somber mo The other members of the group are watching Jimmy and his hairdresser. Then, with a quick, expert move, the hairdresser moves a of JimmyвЂ™s hair to the right. He sticks his fingers in a jar of brilliantine. A middle-aged woman carefully unzips one of the garment b and we get a glimpse of a green outfit.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL POOL. DAWN
dialogues.text: KozelekвЂ™s music swells slightly, moving us even more. The lights in the pool are on, creating a marvelous blue glow. We see Jimmy Tree from the back, his hair quite short. He slowly doing the breaststroke. He gets out, his movements tired, limited, like an old manвЂ™s. He drys himself off starts getting dressed. We still havenвЂ™t seen his face. In the distance, behind the mountains, dawn is breaking. Kozelek's music vanishes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Adolf Hitler, in military uniform, is attempting to strut across the garden, beneath a long canopy. He manages in p thanks to the briarwood cane. His steps are short, uncert in other words, an older Hitler, in his sixties, full of aches and pains. He marches past the camera. ItвЂ™s not Hitler, itвЂ™s Jim in a perfect character reconstruction. He walks slowly, almost prudently, but with an austere, dictatorial demeanor that erases the distinction between Jimmy's character and the real Hitler. He looks around, b no oneвЂ™s there. Then, all of a sudden, Hitler stops. He puts his palm on forehead to smooth down his hair, just as Mick Boyle does the time, and then, with a certain pomposity, gives the N salute. He has saluted Frances, the pale thirteen-year-old girl w stands before him. Jimmy keeps his arm raised, waiting fo reaction. She merely looks calmly at him and smiles, not the least frightened by this unusual performance.  82.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COVERED POOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Mick Boyle is lying on a chaise lounge near the pool, wra in a robe. Lena swims languidly, without much effort. Other than Mick and Lena, thereвЂ™s no one there.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve never told you how sorry I am about how things ended between you and Julian. Lena stops near the edge of the pool. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) I mean, I want to apologize for his behavior.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: вЂњApologize?вЂќ What do you have to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Let's face it, as a father, I could have done more.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Julian did what he wanted to, without worrying about the consequences. He picked up the scent. I'm starting to smell it as well.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What scent?

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: (smiling) The dizzying scent of freedom.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Oh right, I know that scent.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: But Daddy really didnвЂ™t tell you anything about the Queen, about the Simple Songs he was supposed to conduct in London, and how he refused?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: No. He didnвЂ™t tell me a thing.  83.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: What a strange friendship you two have.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Strange? No, itвЂ™s a good friendship. And in a good friendship, you only tell each other the good things. He must have thought that the QueenвЂ™s concert wasnвЂ™t one of them.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: He says he canвЂ™t conduct his вЂњSimple SongsвЂќ because the only person who could sing them was my mother.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (surprised) He said that?

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Yes, that's what he told the Queen's emissary.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: It took him eighty years to finally say something romantic, and who does he go and say it to? The Queen's emissary. Lena smiles. And so does Mick.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: He watches me at night, while I sleep. And tonight, for the first time in my life, he caressed me as I was asleep. Only I wasnвЂ™t asleep, I was pretending.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Parents know when their children are pretending to be asleep. LenaвЂ™s eyes are bright now, and she turns her back to M he canвЂ™t see how touched she is. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Are you worried about him?

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: No, IвЂ™m not worried about him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL DINING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: We're well aware that this hotel is a quiet place, but it never been this silent before.  84. Everyone is looking in the same direction: at the table w Adolf Hitler, indifferent to all those around him, is dig in to a hearty breakfast. And the astounding thing is that theyвЂ™re all looking at deferentially, in awe, as if this were actually the real Hitler, sixty years later. So much so that some of them, passing by him on their way out of the dining room, end u bowing ever so slightly, respectfully, to the fuhrer and saying вЂњGood morning.вЂќ Hitler returns their greeting with the hint of a haughty salute. Then Jimmy/Hitler takes a handkerchief out of his pocket, blows his nose, rubs the tip quickly four times, just as had always seen Fred do, folds it, and puts it back in hi pocket. Fred Ballinger observes Jimmy from his table and, on seei his own habitual gesture reinterpreted by Hitler, smiles strangely. Then the silent German couple stop in front of Hitler and woman stares severely at Jimmy/Hitler. In a serious voice she orders him.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don't you ever dare to do that again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SKI LIFT. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred and Mick, all decked out for trekking (hats, sunglas the latest backpacks, formfitting, orange synthetic T-shi Bermuda shorts, colorful Solomon hiking shoes, and poles) next to each other on the ski lift, suspended in mid-air they climb up to 10,000 feet. They look up at the vertigi peaks and the jagged rock face of the mountains as they s silently upward. After a while.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I talked with Lena a bit this morning. SheвЂ™s worried about you. Fred stares at the mountain peak, impassive. Mick waits, Fred doesnвЂ™t respond. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) It's years since you went to see Melanie. Why don't you go? Venice is so close.  85. Fred is impassive. He doesnвЂ™t say a word. Mick turns to at him, but Fred keeps staring straight ahead, his eyes o the mountain. Mick tries again. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Lena told me about this story with Queen Elizabeth. You didnвЂ™t breathe a word to me about it. Well, it could be pretty nice, no? I'd be so happy to hear Simple Song No. 3 played live one last time.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: You don't want to betray the memory of Melanie, but sometimes, in order to remain faithful, you have to have the courage to betray. Don't you agree? Fred, after a silence, as he looks at the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Mick, thereвЂ™s something that I just canвЂ™t get out of my head.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: What it would have been like to sleep with Gilda Black!

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Yeah! I wonder too! Fred turns to scrutinize Mick, because he doesnвЂ™t trust truth of his words. In a hiss halfway between serious and humorous, he says.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Liar! Mick avoids his friend's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOUNTAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s so beautiful here, the silence and the pure air of mountains at 10,000 feet. Fred and Mick are sitting on a grassy slope that gives on a valley far below. ThereвЂ™s no one there, only the two them and all this nature and silence. Fred unwraps a cand and pops it in his mouth.  86. After a sizeable silence, Fred pierces the soft mountain breeze.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Hey Mick.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Why are we dressed like this? Mick sniggers. There in that immense silence, Fred starts rubbing the ca wrapper in time to some inner music. Mick casts a sidelon glance at his friendвЂ™s fingers.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s not so great.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: The piece youвЂ™re playing with that candy wrapper. YouвЂ™ve done a lot better than that in your lifetime. Now itвЂ™s Fred who sniggers a bit. Then he turns serious

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The hooker's tiny mother, hand in hand with her plump, cl daughter. They walk under the long canopy that runs throu the garden. The neon "Hotel" sign looms above them. They arrive at the hotel entrance. As always, the mother kisses her daughter and then tells her.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Do good things. The daughter enters the hotel. The mother gives her one l look.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE SAUNA POOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Mick and Fred are the only ones sitting on the boiling wo benches. Skinny little towels cover their private parts. They're sweating like pigs. It seems as if they could die any moment. They sit in silence, exhausted from the infernal heat, wh vision brings them back to the spectacle of life.  87. A statuesque woman appears, wrapped in a robe. She takes off. Naked. Her beauty and corporeal perfection are the epitome of sensational. With utmost elegance and feminini this creature - for that is what she is - places a towel the wooden bench and gently reclines. Indifferent to her nakedness and to the two old men, she closes her eyes and relaxes. Not only is this woman completely comfortable, but she se to have been created to make the rest of world uncomforta Fred and Mick, ill at ease, stare at her the way one star at those paranormal - and therefore inexplicable - phenom in nature. It takes them an unreasonable amount of time to regain an semblance of rational thought. They begin whispering to e other, so as not to be overheard by that perfect creature

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean, who is she? Miss Universe.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: She looks completely different, unrecognizable.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: She's been transformed, from watching all those robot movies. Fred doesnвЂ™t laugh. He canвЂ™t. He has to gaze dizzily Universe, whose beauty drains him. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) You know something, Fred? By dint of all our piss talk, we've forgotten that that organ is also made to fulfill other functions.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Take it easy with those illusions, Mick.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Illusions? You know they make these little pills now...

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it distorts the reality of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: And so? And what have I been doing my whole life making films?  88. Miss Universe languidly shifts her legs a few inches, jus enough to inflict further despair on our two old men.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Anyway, sheвЂ™s not interested, Mick, She's interested in a body that corresponds to hers. Sex is like music, it wants harmony. And rightly so. WeвЂ™re no longer in any condition to harmonize with anyone, Mick. They could cry at this point, and they might have, if an attendant hadnвЂ™t come into the sauna just then.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Boyle, thereвЂ™s someone here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (snorts) CanвЂ™t you see that weвЂ™re living the last great idyll of our lives? Well, who's the pain in the neck?

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Brenda Morel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here she is, the genius, Brenda Morel. Who was once a dee mysterious femme fatale. Impeccable, sitting up straight small armchair. Over eighty years old. Numerous face lift delicate diamond choker sparkles among her wrinkles, whic are more obstinate than her plastic surgeon. A cascade of blond hair that make us wonder about her hairdresser. While she waits, she expertly runs her tongue over her en dental arch, making sure that her lipstick hasnвЂ™t stain perfect dentures. Mick enters, sparking an orgy of joy and affectation. But Brenda. She is serious. Aloof.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Brenda! What a fabulous, marvelous surprise!

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Hi, Mick. They kiss each other on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: You look fabulous, Brenda. The very picture of radiance and sex appeal.  89.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: You're getting mixed up with last millennium, Mick. Mick laughs theatrically.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What, you just couldnвЂ™t wait any longer? We just finished the latest version, you know. We were having trouble with the ending, but then yesterday, eureka! it came to us. So now that youвЂ™re here in the flesh, we can hand it to you. But didnвЂ™t you tell me you were going to be in Los Angeles? What are you doing in Europe? Brenda looks Mick in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: How long have we known each other, Mick?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're putting me on the spot! Let me count...

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Fifty-three years. And how many films have we made together?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Nine, ten...

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Eleven. And do you really think that after fifty-three years of friendship and eleven films together that now IвЂ™m going to start bullshitting you, of all people?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (bewildered) No, no I donвЂ™t... I wouldnвЂ™t deserve that.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Right, you donвЂ™t deserve it. You deserve me to call a spade a spade. Which is why I dragged my ass here from LA. To talk to you in person. Brenda's seriousness, her severity, makes Mick anxious.  90.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: I see. Look, Brenda, if itвЂ™s about scene 21, where you're described as вЂњugly, feeble, a pale shadow of your former beauty,вЂќ well, please realize that thatвЂ™s just poetic license, but on set, naturally, we'll proceed in a totally different way. I want you to be extraordinary. You still preserve intact - you have to - that mystery, that allure that made you a diva in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t go licking my ass, Mick, it just breaks my balls even more, especially given what I came here to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Why? What did you come to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not doing the film, Mick.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: They offered me a TV series in New Mexico. A three year contract. An alcoholic grandmother who's had a serious stroke. A character with real balls. With the money IвЂ™1l be able to pay for JackвЂ™s drug rehab, my niece AngelicaвЂ™s film school tuition, pay off my idiotic husbandвЂ™s debts, and still have enough money left over for a house in Miami, which IвЂ™ve been wanting for fourteen years. ThatвЂ™s what I came to tell you. Mick objects, raising his voice.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: But this is cinema, Brenda! ThatвЂ™s just television. TelevisionвЂ™s shit.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: TelevisionвЂ™s the future, Mick. To tell you the truth, itвЂ™s also the present. So letвЂ™s be frank, Mick, because nobody speaks frankly in this fucking film world. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going on eighty, and like most of your colleagues, you've gotten worse with age. The last three films you made were shit, Mick. IвЂ™m telling you, according to me and according to everybody, they were real shit! Mick Boyle is practically having a heart attack. He's shouting in a way he shouldn't, given his age and his hig blood pressure.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: How dare you! How dare you! How dare you! So you want to be frank, do you? Fine, letвЂ™s be frank. Fifty- three years ago, if it werenвЂ™t for me, who was, is, and always will be a gentleman, you would still be crouching under some producerвЂ™s desk. I pulled you out of all those fat producersвЂ™ underpants and made you into an actress. Brenda is fuming, her eyes ablaze. She screams at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: What a little shit you are! I was just fine in those producersвЂ™ underpants. And you know why? Because I wanted to be there. I donвЂ™t owe anybody anything. I did it all myself. I paid my way at the Actors Studio by cleaning toilets all over Brooklyn, my mother went into debt for me. And in Hollywood I walked through the front door, all by myself. Marilyn, Rita, Grace, they'd all shit in their pants when they saw me coming. ItвЂ™s all written down, right there in my autobiography, donвЂ™t tell me you haven't read it?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately I have. Except you didnвЂ™t write it. And it was a piece of shit, your autobiography, just like this TV series youвЂ™re going to do, real shit. Brenda sighs, as if she needed air, but then, surprisingl she stops shouting. She calms down and starts speaking in quiet voice that makes her seem even more ruthless than w she was yelling.  92.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: The real shit is this film of yours, Mick. I understand cinema, you know I do. YouвЂ™re the one who doesnвЂ™t understand it any more. Because youвЂ™re old, youвЂ™re tired, you donвЂ™t know how to see the world any more, all you know how to see is your own death, which is waiting right around the corner for you. Your careerвЂ™s over, Mick. IвЂ™m telling you flat out because I love you. No oneвЂ™s interested in your testament, as you call it, and you risk nullifying all the beautiful films you've already made. And that would be unforgivable. It was only because of me that they were even going to let you make it. So by pulling out, IвЂ™m saving your life. And your dignity. Mick is devastated. Completely drained. His words are cutting.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™re an ingrate. And ingrate and an idiot. Which is why you got ahead. But Brenda doesnвЂ™t hear his insults any more. Or maybe just doesnвЂ™t believe them. Regardless, she stretches ou diamond-encrusted hand and does something extraordinary: caresses MickвЂ™s cheek. Mick is on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: You're right, Mick, thatвЂ™s exactly right. Mick hisses between his teeth, his words full of hatred a revenge.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m going to make this film anyway. Even without you. Mick is crying. Brenda is still caressing his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Come on, Mick, life goes on. Even without all this cinema bullshit. Mick buries his face in his hands, destroyed. Brenda, like the last of the great movie stars, stands up smooths out her dress, which has gotten a few creases in grabs her thirty-thousand dollar purse, and with a regal, dignified gait, makes her exit.  93.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Spring must be coming to an end, because itвЂ™s the mime tonight. The whole nine yards: tails, whiteface, that per melancholy expression. In a corner, the man we saw earlier, all covered in mud, approaches Miss Universe.

dialogues.speaker: MUD MAN
dialogues.text: Do you know you are the paragon of human beauty?

dialogues.speaker: MISS UNIVERSE
dialogues.text: Do you know I was just thinking the same thing? The man walks away without uttering another word. The mime pretends to climb over an imaginary wall, but without success. Mick and Jimmy Tree, who has changed back in his own clot are watching the performance. TheyвЂ™re sitting next to e other, with Fred and Lena. Mick is catatonic. He looks but doesnвЂ™t see, staring of space with a monotonous expression.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Do you know how many actresses IвЂ™ve worked with in my carrier?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Lots... I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (venting) More than fifty. I launched at least fifty actresses. And theyвЂ™ve always been grateful to me. I... IвЂ™m aa great womenвЂ™s director. Fred and Lena turn to look at Mick, but they canвЂ™t find right words or the right expression. Jimmy Tree stares into Mick's eyes and play acts.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: вЂњThat way, Frank, that way youвЂ™ll never forget me.вЂќ Do you remember, Mr. Boyle?

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Of course I remember. I remember everything I ever shot.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY TREE
dialogues.text: Mr. Boyle, youвЂ™re not a great womenвЂ™s director. YouвЂ™re a great director, period. The mime, exhausted from not being able to climb over the wall, crumbles to the ground and pretends to fall asleep. Fred Ballinger is looking at the mime. Lena is looking at her father. The hippy mountaineer is looking at Lena. There is a brief round of applause for the mime. The audience begins to disperse. The evening is over. Mic Fred, and Lena are heading off when the voice of the boy violinist calls out loudly, making them stop.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Mr. Ballinger. They turn around. The boy has ascended the stage and, vio in hand, plays the first, simple chords of Simple Song No All he can play are the first two chords, but heвЂ™s gott lot better. He plays them well and, even though he can on repeat them, their sweetness has the power to move anyone listens. Everyone is hypnotized by the child's simple playing. Jim Tree, Mark Kozelek and his friends, the mountaineer, Lena the South American and his wife, the German couple, all t elderly guests and their caretakers, the vulgar Russians, the black family, Frances and her mother, the waiters and doctor, the hotel manager and the cooks: itвЂ™s as if tim standing still, like in a fairy tale where every, stars a extras, join together. But only one person is truly moved by those simple violin notes. And itвЂ™s not Fred Ballinger, itвЂ™s Mick Boyle. tears in his eyes. And only Fred Ballinger, of all the people there, has not that Mick is moved. Fred looks at him impassively.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL GYM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Lena, in a beautiful evening dress, stands at the foot of free-climbing wall, scrutinizing the height of the fake r face. The mountaineer must have followed her because heвЂ™s com behind her now. He approaches warily, intimidated, heвЂ™s almost reached her.  95. A bundle of nerves and embarrassment, he adjusts his shir surreptitiously straightens his hair, and then appears at side. Lena doesnвЂ™t even look at him, as if he didnвЂ™t He delivers an awkward opener.

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAINEER
dialogues.text: Would you like to try to climb? Only at this point does Lena suddenly turn toward him. Sh pierces him with a look that could not be more sensual, a then addresses him in a serious, husky voice.

dialogues.speaker: LENA
dialogues.text: Do you know that I can make a man go wild in bed if I want? The mountaineer, as though it were the only natural thing do, looks up, goes white as milk, and falls to the ground a faint. A loud thud. Lena immediately abandons the role of the "femme fatale" becomes the apprehensive friend. She exclaims to herself.

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, fucking hell! She leans over the mountaineer lying on the floor. She sl his cheeks to revive him. SheвЂ™s scared.

dialogues.speaker: LENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, sir! Wake up, fuck! Slowly the mountaineer comes to. He opens his eyes and se Lena's worried face a few inches from his. In a faint voice, the mountaineer says.

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAINEER
dialogues.text: It takes a lot less for you to make aman go wild. Lena smiles, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOTEL LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The chubby hooker sits alone on a couch, looking sad. The lobby is deserted. Mick appears behind her and, without mincing his words, says.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Okay, I've made up my mind, I went to the ATM. The hooker turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: And what would you want to do?  96.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: (serious) Go for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOTEL GARDEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mick Boyle and the unattractive hooker stroll hand in han like new lovers, through the garden with its centuries-ol trees. ThatвЂ™s all they do. They donвЂ™t even look at each othe they walk slowly, hand in hand. While on a secluded bench, the two screenwriters suspecte falling in love are, in fact, in love. They kiss with tha intensity of first kisses. Endless, exhausting kisses. Al a sudden, the female screenwriter, without stopping kissi sees Mick and the young lady out of the corner of her eye

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOUNTAIN VILLAGE. TRAIN STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: The small train station in this mountain village. Mick Boyle and the five screenwriters, all of them blue, side by side on a bench on the platform, waiting for the train. The two lovers are holding hands. After a silence, Mick breaks the ice.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Come on, kids, whatвЂ™s with the long faces? Hitches, delays in screening, these things are constants in our line of work. Get used to it. IвЂ™ve already talked with the producer, we just need a little time to come up with another actress and then the shooting starts. ItвЂ™s just a matter of waiting a few more months.

dialogues.speaker: INTELLECTUAL SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: What a bitch that Brenda Morel is.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Don't talk like that about Brenda Morel.

dialogues.speaker: SCREENWRITER IN LOVE
dialogues.text: She goes where the wind blows.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Which is what we all do. And it's what you all will do, in order to survive in this jungle.  97.

dialogues.speaker: SHY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: It's not true that she came to Europe specially to meet you, Mick. I read that she's going to Cannes, some charity ball at the Film Festival. The other screenwriters throw him dirty looks.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Let's not get carried away with all this truth, now. Remember that fiction is our passion.

dialogues.speaker: FUNNY SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Your film-testament is worth a whole lot more than one more TV series, Mick.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: My film-testament!? Let's not overrate things. Most men die not only without a testament, but without anyone even noticing.

dialogues.speaker: INTELLECTUAL SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: Most men arenвЂ™t great artists like you.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: It makes no difference. Men, artists, animals, plants - we're all just extras. The train has arrived. The doors open. The screenwriters their backpacks and start boarding the train. The last to climb aboard is the female screenwriter who hasnвЂ™t yet word. Mick stays on the platform, watching them. Just bef the door closes, she turns to Mick and, with a beautiful smile, says.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE SCREENWRITER
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s on his deathbed, and he dies. Only then does she say - and for the first time - "I love you, Michael." Mick smiles, moved.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Perfect! The door closes. The train pulls away and disappears arou bend. Mick, sad now, turns and leaves the station.  98.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY LANE. DAY
dialogues.text: Mick, alone and disappointed, shuffles along the same cou lane. HeвЂ™s all alone. ItвЂ™s a glorious day. Brilliant Blue sky. Crisp air. Chirping cicadas. A paradise. A woman's voice, as if it were coming from nowhere, calls him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mick. Mick turns to his left, where there is an immense uncultivated field, the grass three feet high. He looks, canвЂ™t see anyone. But then, a woman dressed like a 1950 stewardess materializes out of the grass. It was she who called him, and now she adds anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to say this line, Mick? I donвЂ™t get it. Mick doesnвЂ™t even have time to respond before another w she looks like a young Jean Seberg - pops up from the gra wearing a bikini. She sounds as if she is reciting a line from a film, in an ostentatious, snobby voice.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL IN BIKINI
dialogues.text: You may not know, James, that I never even step foot on a yacht that is less then 80 feet. Next a ditsy blond with abundant curves, 1960s style, app out of the grass, and starts reciting.

dialogues.speaker: DITSY BLOND
dialogues.text: Come on, guys, where did you hide my lilac slippers? Enough already. Mick watches and smiles radiantly. Now a pious looking, middle-aged woman pops up and recite emotionally, on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: PIOUS WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh Albert, if only you knew how much it has cost me to guard my virginity all these years, until today, until I met you! A magnificent countess in a nineteenth-century gown rises out of the grass.  99.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS
dialogues.text: Prince, I am the owner of six castles and twenty carriages, but there is only one thing I can declare with certainty: life is so tiresome. And now a woman in the militant dress of 1968.

dialogues.speaker: 1968ER
dialogues.text: Sure, we all want a revolution, as long as it doesnвЂ™t tire us out too much. Mick looks happily at all his actresses, one by one, as t recite lines from his films. Another woman appears, about thirty-five, her back to us, long, flowing red hair and bare shoulders. She turns to t camera: a fabulous, authentic diva, dripping with allure. gives a sensual, nostalgic performance.

dialogues.speaker: DIVA
dialogues.text: Okay, you win, I'll go to bed with you, but on one condition. That you donвЂ™t come. That way, Frank, that way you'll never forget me. One after another all of MickвЂ™s actresses appear, poppi out of the grass. Each one recites a line. The ones that been standing for a while just keep repeating the same li in a quieter voice. In short, that field becomes a garden of actresses - all types, all ages and eras, in all sorts of costumes (a soldier, a little old lady, a drag queen, a vamp, a singe gymnast, a ballerina with a tutu, etc.), all reciting the lines for Mick. The whining stewardess again.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: How do you want it, Mick? Sincere, smug, wicked? And my walk? HowвЂ™s my character supposed to move? Mick is about to reply when yet another actress pops up a steals his attention. More than all the others, this one really shakes him up. He blurts out.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Mommy . All the other actresses fall silent, leaving the stage to this last actress.  100. ItвЂ™s Brenda Morel, in costume: a cheap, ugly dressing g decrepit, a pale shadow of her former beauty. She recites a neutral voice.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: You were so cute when you were little, my boy. But whatвЂ™s so disgraceful is that youвЂ™re still cute. A cute, useless man. MickвЂ™s eyes are shining. The silence of the empty field ThereвЂ™s no one there. The vision is over. 64. INT. FRED BALLINGERвЂ™S SUITE. DAY Fred and Mick are in FredвЂ™s bedroom. Fred in the armchair, Mick on the edge of the bed. Mick i looking out the window. Calm and disappointed. Fred eyes knowing what a difficult moment this is for his friend.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: So you talked to the producer? Mick turns and looks at Fred.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™ve been in this business too long not to know that without Brenda, this film is never going to be made. Silence. Mick reflects. Then Mick turns his gaze to FredвЂ™s night stand. He look the photograph of Fred and his wife hugging ten years earlier. Old, but happy. And beautiful. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) Melanie is so beautiful in that picture.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: You're right, she is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: You know, IвЂ™ve come to realize something, Fred. People are either beautiful or ugly. The ones in between are merely cute. Fred smiles bitterly. So does Mick. MICK BOYLE (CONTвЂ™D) So... another vacation almost over. What will you do next, Fred?  101.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do? IвЂ™1l go home, the usual routine.

dialogues.speaker: MICK BOYLE
dialogues.text: Not me. I donвЂ™t do routine. You know what IвЂ™m going to do, Fred? IвЂ™m going to start on another film. You say that emotions are overrated, but that's bullshit. Emotions are all we have. Then Mick gets up, goes over to the glass door, opens it, steps onto the balcony, and, with remarkable simplicity, one foot on the wicker chair, the other on the railing, a lets himself fall from the fifth floor. Fred barely has time to stand up. Mick was so swift and s unpredictable, he didnвЂ™t give his friend time to do any to save him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AIRPLANE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Boeing sits on the runway. In the background, the mountains. In a LONG SHOT from the back of the plane, we watch the entire take off. The plane is full. We can see the back o everybodyвЂ™s necks from this angle. A stewardess strolls down the aisle. She turns politely t distinguished looking man.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, but youвЂ™1ll have to switch off your cell phone. The LONG SHOT continues. All of a sudden, from the other end of the plane - from business class, which is separated by a little curtain fr where we are - comes a hoarse, monstrous cry. It goes on on, a broken, bloodcurdling sound. All the passengers stretch their necks toward the little curtain, surprised. The stewardess dashes at full speed toward business class. The camera begins a long, slow tracking shot down the ais toward business class. As the dolly moves, the monstrous, deranged screams, whic seem to be those of a woman, echo throughout the cabin. M female cries, and the sound of a scuffle. The camera has arrived at the little curtain. It makes it way under it and enters business class.  102. The screams still persist, but theyвЂ™re fading now. By now all the passengers are on their feet, gawking. The camera elbows its way to the passageway in front of t cockpit and the exit door. We hear a jumble of confused voices, a muffled moan, and incomprehensible commotion. The camera has arrived at the center of the action: five stewardesses, done in by the physical strain, are literal immobilizing someone on the floor. One of them has a bloo lip. The camera goes to find out who it is, moaning and shakin feebly. ItвЂ™s Brenda Morel stretched out there on the floor of t plane, deranged, her torn dress riding up, revealing an o lady's flesh-colored slip, her make-up smudged, her face barely recognizable, disfigured by pain and tears, her wo fragmented and incomprehensible, frightening. She is bald. Her wig must have fallen off in the scuffle the stewardesses. A close-up of BrendaвЂ™s face. We now realize what she is saying. Exhausted but determined, she keeps mumbling to t stewardesses who are holding her down.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Let me off, you fucking bitches, let me off this damn plane immediately. The pilot comes out of the cockpit, breathless. He speaks Brenda.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Okay, lady, you win. I just got clearance from the control tower. We're going to let you off now.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILL. DAY
dialogues.text: Scattered across the hill, the usual cows with their bell ringing randomly. Fred is sitting on a rock facing them. He watches the animals, his face blank. Then he closes his eyes. The camera zooms in slowly. Fred moves his arm, as if directing an orchestra, but this tim nothing happens. The cowbells keep ringing in random, anarchic fashion.  103. Fred, his eyes still closed, makes a vexed gesture. He mo his arm more energetically this time, but still nothing. canвЂ™t seem to concentrate and compose in his mind. He is in need of music, but music no longer has need of h He opens his eyes. The cows are still there, in front of And in a loud voice he issues a command, a pretty stupid thing to say to a bunch of cows.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Be quiet. But the cows and their cowbells ignore him. Fred drops his head slightly. HeвЂ™s exhausted. His eyes with grief. Then, something surprising happens. Without any warning, parachutist lands silently in the middle of the cows. Fred looks at him. The parachute collapses on top of the covering him completely. He struggles to free himself, then looks around in surpri and realizes he has landed in the wrong place, right in t middle of a herd of cows. He looks at Fred and says calmly.

dialogues.speaker: PARACHUTIST
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t think this was where I was supposed to land. And, without waiting for a reply, he heads off across the hill. As Fred watches him, his eyes still wet with tears, he smiles. 67. INT. DOCTORвЂ™S OFFICE. DAY A magnificent bow window that looks out onto the mountain with an antique wooden birdcage. ItвЂ™s a gorgeous, round structure, with a magnificent blackbird inside. The bird is chirping a simple, perfect song. We are in the office of the sixty-year-old doctor. He is standing behind his desk, staring with dismay and concern Fred Ballinger, who is sitting on the other side of the d ecstatically contemplating the singing blackbird. The doctor beings in a tactful voice.  104.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Will you be going to Los Angeles for the funer-- Fred interrupts him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Ssshhhh! The doctor falls silent. Fred, his face vacant, stands up and shuffles over to the window, to hear the birdвЂ™s song up close. The doctor too turns and looks at the bird, which suddenl and for no apparent reason - stops singing. Fred turns to the doctor and says, all in one go. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Birds are such artists! No, IвЂ™m not going to Los Angeles. IвЂ™m not going to Mick BoyleвЂ™s funeral. And I won't come back here on holiday either. Because itвЂ™s absolutely pointless to return to the places where you have been happy. Because you have to learn how to look everything else in the face. The doctor nods sadly. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) Why exactly did you call me in here, doctor? What is it you wanted to tell me? The doctor sits on his desk. He picks up a medical file a opens it.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I have the results of all the check- ups youвЂ™ve been doing during your holiday.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: And what do they say?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You're as healthy as a horse, Mr. Ballinger. Fred, hopeful almost, asks.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: My prostate at least? The doctor is surprised.  105.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Your prostate? YouвЂ™ve never had a problem with your prostate. And if you havenвЂ™t had any problems so far, you're certainly not going to start having them now. Fred looks up at the doctor. Completely unexpectedly, he smiles. And says.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: So IвЂ™ve grown old, but without understanding how I got here. The doctor gives him a sad smile. Fred turns and looks out the window. In the distance, he spots the young masseuse who is quickly crossing the hote garden in her white work smock. She moves quickly and gracefully, and Fred watches her with that same tinge of melancholy, while the doctor says to him.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: So... do you know what awaits you outside of here?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No, doctor, what?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (smiles) Youth. The doctor reflects for a moment, growing sad.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mick Boyle used to come by pretty often for a chat. Fred watches the masseuse disappear behind a row of trees jump into the pool. Then he asks the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: By any chance, did he ever tell you anything about Gilda Black?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He never talked about anything else. Fred's ears perk up. HeвЂ™s consumed by curiosity. But he to hide it, in order to get the answers he is after.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: Was she his girlfriend?  106.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: вЂњGirlfriendвЂќ is way too much. The only thing that ever happened was one time, when they were kids, they held hands and walked together for a few yards in some park. Fred smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He used to call it "The moment I learned to ride a bike." DidnвЂ™t he ever tell you about it?

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: No. We only ever told each other the good things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Especially at night, when the city is still, deserted, abandoned seeming, when even the most diehard tourists ha fallen into the arms of Morpheus. Canals, narrow streets, Saint MarkвЂ™s Square. Everything unmoving and statuesque. But then he appears. In the distance, small and vulnerabl with that tiny, old-man shuffle of his. And flowers, heвЂ carrying flowers. ItвЂ™s Fred Ballinger. HeвЂ™s walking a himself through this mysterious city. He crosses a small bridge. A motorboat glides underneath, not making a sound

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CEMETERY. DAWN
dialogues.text: A speedboat-taxi skirts the walls of the cemetery. Fred Ballinger sits onboard, serious and tired, staring into t void, the flowers in his lap. In the cemetery, he crosses the long avenues dotted with tombs. HeвЂ™s looking for someone. He approaches a few to but canвЂ™t remember. And besides, he doesnвЂ™t have much sense of direction. There, heвЂ™s finally found it. He stands in front of the of Igor Stravinsky. But he keeps holding the flowers firm in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred knows the way now. He shuffles along a narrow street that borders a canal. He turns a corner and stops. He loo up sadly and sees the sign for a private clinic.  107.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLINIC. PRIVATE ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Fred, flowers in hand, stands in a room of the clinic. A sober, private room. And he looks. HeвЂ™s looking at a be the window where we see from behind an elderly woman, motionless, her hair loose, her forehead leaning against window. Fred plucks up his courage and arranges the flowers in a small plastic vase on the night stand. Then he pulls the photo he had in the hotel out of his pocket and places it next to the flowers. He sits down near her, his back to h He looks at the floor and, filled with an unusual shyness says.

dialogues.speaker: FRED BALLINGER
dialogues.text: I waited till it was visiting hours to come see you. Fred stares at the woman's back under the sheet. Fred is expressionless. There is no noise. Then, without emotion, without any intonation, Fred begin talk, in a simple, unhurried manner. FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) They donвЂ™t know, Melanie. Children canвЂ™t know their parentsвЂ™ ordeals. Sure, they know certain details, the most striking elements, those they know. They know what they need to know in order to side with one or the other. They need to simplify things. And theyвЂ™re right. But they donвЂ™t know. They canвЂ™t know. They donвЂ™t know how I trembled the first time I saw you on that stage. And the orchestra laughing behind my back at my falling in love, at my unexpected fragility. They donвЂ™t know that you sold your motherвЂ™s jewelry so I could finish my second piece, when everyone was turning me down and saying I was a presumptuous, inelegant musician. They donвЂ™t know that you too - and you were right - thought at the time that I was a presumptuous, inelegant musician, and you cried nonstop, not because you had sold your motherвЂ™s jewels but because you had sold your mother. They donвЂ™t know how you loved me, and how I loved you. Only we know that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED BALLINGER (CONTвЂ™D) They donвЂ™t know what we were together, you and I, despite everything. And that вЂњdespite everythingвЂќ that was so exhausting, so painful, so hard. Melanie, they can never know that we two, despite everything, liked to think of ourselves as a simple song. HeвЂ™s done. He gets up from his chair and stands on his as if trying to see his wifeвЂ™s face, but he gives up immediately. He canвЂ™t handle it emotionally. So he simp stretches out his hand and moves his wifeвЂ™s arm few inc so that it is in what he hopes is a more comfortable position.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VENICE. HOSPITAL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fred leaves the hospital. He walks toward the camera unti have a close up of his face. Behind him, on the mezzanine glimpse FredвЂ™s wife, her forehead leaning against the g and her mouth open. But only a glimpse, because from here she seems so far aw Fred stands still and reflects. He starts to turn around, look back at his wife, but he canвЂ™t bring himself to. H desists and looks straight ahead again. Then he takes a c from his pocket, unwraps it, and pops it in his mouth. He tries again to turn toward his wife, who is still ther far away, behind the glass, as if she were watching him instead of merely staring at nothing. But once again, Fre doesnвЂ™t have the courage to look her in the face. He ho the candy wrapper between his fingers, but this time he doesnвЂ™t rub it. He throws it in the canal in front of h Tired and tested, Fred reflects. And as he does so, ina close up shot, the violin from вЂњSimple Song No.3вЂќ beg sound, but this time, we sense right away, it is played b violin virtuoso, not a boy just starting out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. EVENING
dialogues.text: Absolute silence, two empty chairs with gold trim. An elegantly dressed audience has filled the theater. Without warning, without any signal, the entire audience rises to its feet in eerie silence. Two individuals have entered the theater. We catch a glimpse of them through t backdrop of people. Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip. They sit in the gold trimmed chairs. We see their royal outlines backlit by the lights of the stage.  109. The audience can sit down again. A violin virtuoso plays the opening bars of вЂњSimple Son No.3вЂќ. Adagio, moderate volume. Prince Philip, in a backlit shot, his eyes full of joy, expectant and excited. The eyes of a child. On the stage, the great South Korean soprano, Sumi Jo, swallows secretly, overcome with panic and emotion. She g ready to sing. Backlit, Queen Elizabeth glances at her consort and is ha The QueenвЂ™s emissary, in the back of a box, observes fr afar the happy Queen and Prince Philip, but he is still a ball of tension. Sumi Jo opens her mouth wide and practically knocks the h down when she breaks into a perfect, heart-rending love s The large audience of extremely elegant guests jumps out their chairs slightly, as if hypnotized by the sopranoвЂ™ voice. Sumi Jo's high note is over. It didnвЂ™t last long. Fred Ballinger, concentrating intensely, in perfect contr of himself, gracefully waves his baton, and the entire orchestra joins in. Strings and wind instruments play in unison, the music rises, and the whole audience gets goos bumps. Jimmy Tree is there, alone, without any of his friends. H leans forward slowly on his chair; his eyes shine with childlike excitement. It's beautiful, this plaintive Simple Song No.3 as it unfolds...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOUNTAIN CLIFF. DAY
dialogues.text: +. close ups of Lena and the hippy mountaineer. Very clos together. Close enough to kiss, if she werenвЂ™t tremblin much. He laughs, like a moron. TheyвЂ™re so close. Then he stop laughing. He looks at her. He holds her close. She stops trembling. She looks at him. We know they will kiss, but not now. The camera zooms out.  110. Lena and the mountaineer are hanging in mid-air at ten thousand feet. Nothing below them. She clinging to him. K alive by a rope and some carabiners.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. EVENING
dialogues.text: Fred waves his arm and the strings and winds grow fainter until they finally disappear. Just the violin now. Fred looks at Sumi Jo. He signals with his eyes for her t come in. Sumi Jo opens her mouth again, another clamorous, long, perfect high note. Fred canвЂ™t help but stare at the Japanese soprano as sh delivers that extraordinary sound. And she looks at him. Fred keeps looking at her, but itвЂ™s as if he is seeing someone else...

dialogues.text: .В»В». as if heвЂ™s seeing her. His wife Melanie. Sumi Jo's high note continues in this scene. The camera zooms in slowly on the hospital mezzanine. A c up of Melanie. Her loose white hair, her face ravaged by disease, her eyes lost in an abyss, and her mouth open, a she were singing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATER. EVENING
dialogues.text: A close-up of Sumi Jo, mouth open, still hitting that hig note. Fred Ballinger looks at her, skillfully hiding any emotio Sumi Jo looks at Fred Ballinger. She waits. And, at the c closing of his hand, she suddenly, skillfully, ends that crazy high note. The orchestra moves to the conclusion. With a sharp, clear movement of his wand, Fred Ballinger brings the music to a close. The orchestra stops. Absolute silence. The world has stopped spinning.  111. The QueenвЂ™s emissary lets out a huge sigh of relief. It over. Jimmy Tree is sitting upright in his chair, his mouth hal open, as if suspended in astonishment and excitement. He waits to see what will happen next. Slowly, with learned gestures, Fred Ballinger turns towar the audience. No self-satisfaction, at least not now. He is impassive, a sphinx, a professional. Yes, thatвЂ™s he is, a professional. The members of the audience fan out below him. Their eyes wet, deeply moved. Fred Ballinger, imperturbable, waits for them to recover the emotion. He knows that they need a few more seconds f emotion to give way to applause. We know they will applaud, but not now. Not yet. And in the silence, FADE TO BLACK. Slowly, calmly, the closing credits begin. Paolo Sorrentino April 2014
